name: United States
notes_C1: Burbio lists between 1.5% - 3.5% of students attending class fully online, with an additional 20-35% attending hybrid-type classes as of May 24. While a majority of students is attending class in-person, this  almost assuredly remains a 2T. Additionally, as of 07 June 2021, New York City has only partially opened all schools, with full services only fully planned to return with the new school year in September. Other evidence also points to potential school closures in American Samoa, Bureau of Indian Education schools, Montana, and Wyoming.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210607201137/https://info.burbio.com/school-tracker-update-may-24/    https://web.archive.org/web/20210607201125/https://www.npr.org/2021/05/24/999825807/new-york-city-schools-will-fully-reopen-with-no-remote-option-this-fall?t=1623096665316    https://web.archive.org/web/20210607195535/https://www.edweek.org/leadership/map-coronavirus-and-school-closures-in-2019-2020/2020/03
notes_C2: An executive order issued by Gov. Kevin Stitt on March 12 lifted all statewide restrictions on events and residents. This includes any occupancy restrictions for offices.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210607215752/https://www.northstarmeetingsgroup.com/News/Industry/Coronavirus-states-cities-reopening-COVID-19-new-cases#Oklahoma    https://web.archive.org/web/20210425023830/https://www.sos.ok.gov/documents/executive/1992.pdf (previous order which was replaced by the order below)  https://web.archive.org/web/20210425030825/https://www.sos.ok.gov/documents/executive/1984.pdf (new order which makes no mention of any restrictions to residents or offices anymore)
notes_C3: A significant number of states have at least some restrictions still in place. However, North Carolina has lifted all event restrictions (including social distancing requirements) on May 14. Utah has no firm restrictions in place, only recommendations for events. New Jersey has lifted all event restrictions (other than enforcing social distancing) on indoor and outdoor events on June 4th. Hence, 1T is the correct coding.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210607215752/https://www.northstarmeetingsgroup.com/News/Industry/Coronavirus-states-cities-reopening-COVID-19-new-cases
notes_C4: Parts of California remain under a 10-people-indoors gathering restriction until at least June 15. 4 counties remain in such a tier as of June 08.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210607215752/https://www.northstarmeetingsgroup.com/News/Industry/Coronavirus-states-cities-reopening-COVID-19-new-cases  https://web.archive.org/web/20210607220356/https://covid19.ca.gov/safer-economy/
notes_C5: Public transport in some parts of the country are operating without any restrictions. While ridership is lower than pre-pandemic, this is not the case because of restrictions but rather due to a higher share of telecommuters.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210607224109/https://apnews.com/article/coronavirus-government-and-politics-environment-and-nature-politics-lifestyle-56d36574e38cec038f77339ef12076bc    https://web.archive.org/web/20210607215752/https://www.northstarmeetingsgroup.com/News/Industry/Coronavirus-states-cities-reopening-COVID-19-new-cases#Oklahoma
notes_C6: Though most states have ceased to give any blanket recommendations, at least the state of Massachussets continues to state the following in their COVID guidance: "Even if you do not have symptoms, stay home as much as you can and practice social distancing if you must go out."    https://web.archive.org/web/20210606135614/https://www.mass.gov/info-details/covid-19-prevention-and-treatment
notes_C7: Most states have lifted any travel requirements or travel recommendations. However, Hawaii continues to restrict travel to the island and *to some islands within*: Gov. David Ige (D) issued a proclamation that will allow fully vaccinated travelers to bypass quarantine or testing requirements. Travelers will be required to upload valid documents to the state’s Safe Travel program or otherwise show validation. Alternatively, travelers arriving in Hawaii from out of state must either show a negative COVID-19 test result obtained within 72 hours pre-travel or self-quarantine for 10 days. Some islands require a second test, post-arrival. Visitors to Kauai must quarantine for 10 days, with or without a negative test result.    Kansas also continues to require quarantine for arrivals from certain states.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210607201653/https://www.aarp.org/politics-society/government-elections/info-2020/coronavirus-state-restrictions.html
notes_C8: Travel limitations continue on certain countries.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210521125456/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/from-other-countries.html
notes_E1: Changed to 1 to reflect the fact that Pandemic Unemployment Assistance is only available for 13 weeks. Non-formal workers can apply.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210522091749/https://www.dol.gov/coronavirus/unemployment-insurance
notes_E2: https://ncdoj.gov/covid19/economic-relief/
notes_H1: COVID-19 PUBLIC EDUCATION CAMPAIGN - https://web.archive.org/web/20210523001425/https://wecandothis.hhs.gov/
notes_H2: As per the CDC Testing guidelines, Test is generally available - https://web.archive.org/web/20210523001428/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/symptoms-testing/testing.html
notes_H3: Contact tracing is conducted on a statewide level, and is often further decentralized by county or local health departments or contracted out to private organizations. Not all states report their contact tracing statistics, so it is difficult to gauge the efficacy of contact tracing.     According to the CDC Covid-19 data dashboard, 8.25% of tests were positive over the past 7 days (as of April 14). As an example of contact tracing efforts, for the week of April 4, Oregon's contact tracers reached 84% of Covid-19 cases identified within a 24 hour period. Their goal is to reach 95% of cases. During the same timeframe, only 36.2% of positive cases were traced to a known source, and their goal is to trace at least 70% of cases to a known source.     Funds from the American Rescue Plan (signed into law March 11) are meant to provide technical assistance to states, municipalities, territories, and tribes to help trace and monitor the spread of Covid-19.     CDC: https://archive.vn/yvN69    Link to Plan text: https://web.archive.org/web/20210414214206/https://www.congress.gov/bill/117th-congress/house-bill/1319/text    Link to Oregon data: https://web.archive.org/web/20210414221835/https://public.tableau.com/profile/oregon.health.authority.covid.19
notes_H6: States like Nevada require masks to be worn at all times outside the house.    State by State Policies - https://web.archive.org/web/20210523000047/https://www.aarp.org/politics-society/government-elections/info-2020/coronavirus-state-restrictions.html
notes_H7: https://covid19.ncdhhs.gov/vaccines  https://web.archive.org/web/20210524014821/https://covid19.ncdhhs.gov/vaccines

name: Alaska
notes_C1: Original note by Erin Kanzig: Beginning April 12, Juneau’s middle and high school students will be returning to school four days a week. The change expands the in-person high school schedule by one day and the middle school schedule by two days. Wednesday will remain a distance-learning day at all levels. Students can choose to continue with remote distance learning if they wish.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210407192221/https://www.juneauempire.com/news/school-district-announces-expansion-of-in-person-learning/    Coding updated by Reviewer Monika Pyarali to reflect previous changes (see note on March 15)
notes_C2: Anchorage's Emergency Order 19 remains in effect as of April 7. All restaurants, bars, breweries, and night clubs can open at reduced capacity to maintain physical distancing. Indoor entertainment facilities, indoor gyms and fitness centers can also operated with reduced capacity (masks required). Establishments offering sit-down service of any kind must have visitor logs in order to assist with contact tracing. Employers must require employees to work from home if remote work is feasible.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210407193145/https://www.muni.org/covid-19/documents/final%20signed%20eo19.pdf
notes_C3: Rachelle Koch (Reviewer) Edit:    Coded changed to 1T (from 2T) according to Attachments C and D of Anchorage Emergency Order 20 (enacted 17 April 2021). Attachment C allows for entertainment facilities to open at a capacity that allows for six feet of physical distancing and other COVID-19 related safety measures. Attachment D allows for organized sports with similar stipulations for spectators.    Anchorage EO-20 (enacted 17 April 2021):  https://web.archive.org/web/20210427202830/https://www.muni.org/covid-19/documents/emergencyorder20-final-signed.pdf  Attachment C on entertainment venues:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210427203849/https://www.muni.org/covid-19/documents/eo-20%20attachment%20c%20-%20entertainment%2041221.pdf  Attachment D on organized sports:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210414174904/https://www.muni.org/covid-19/documents/eo-20%20attachment%20d%20-%20organized%20sports%2041221%20230pm.pdf
notes_C4: On April 17, Anchorage will lift all limits on outdoor gathering with mask and social distancing measure still in effect. Restrictions on indoor gathering (~35 people) will still be in place.    Source:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210414200618/https://apnews.com/article/alaska-anchorage-coronavirus-pandemic-2d11a1668c1c3bd6f0dc6dd9bf39975f    https://web.archive.org/web/20210412225928/https://www.adn.com/alaska-news/anchorage/2021/04/12/read-the-full-text-of-anchorages-emergency-order-lifting-outdoor-gathering-limitations/
notes_C5: The People Mover in Anchorage continues to operate with safety measures in place, " People Mover and AnchorRIDES continue to operate regular service and rider limits remain at 14-riders per 40-foot bus and 6-riders per vehicle on the neighborhood routes with 22-foot buses. Cloth face coverings are still required to ride People Mover."     https://archive.vn/II4oD
notes_C6: Anchorage's EO-19 encourages people to avoid contact with those outside their household and to limit trips outside the home.    Health Advisory No. 1 also remains in effect statewide ("Minimize time indoors with individuals outside your household even if you can maintain a distance of six feet. Avoid all gatherings, even small ones, with persons who are not in your household.")     https://web.archive.org/web/20210407194808/https://covid19.alaska.gov/wp-content/uploads/2021/02/02.14.21-Health-Advisory-1-Recommendations.pdf    https://web.archive.org/web/20210407193145/https://www.muni.org/covid-19/documents/final%20signed%20eo19.pdf
notes_C7: According to Health Advisory 2, the State do not restrict or limit any internal movement in Alaska. While general recommendation against against traveling for those tested COVID positive still in place.     Source:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210603193248/https://covid19.alaska.gov/wp-content/uploads/2021/04/04.26.21-Health-Advisory-3-Intrastate-Travel.pdf
notes_C8: No new updates. Policy last updated 30 April 2021.    The CDC states:   "With specific exceptions, several Presidential proclamations suspend and limit entry into the United States, as immigrants or nonimmigrants, of noncitizens who were physically present within the following countries during the 14-day period preceding their entry or attempted entry into the United States." This includes fully vaccinated people. See webpage for list of countries.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210618023101/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/from-other-countries.html
notes_E1: Unemployment assistance is available. The Division of Public Assistance lists other resources available to Alaskans on their website.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210410211043/https://labor.alaska.gov/COVID-19-programs.htm    https://web.archive.org/web/20210410211545/https://cse.google.com/cse.js?cx=c0fe050eb6ce15f1d
notes_E2: There are no active statewide moratoriums or suspensions of utility shutoffs. The CDC eviction moratorium is in effect. Those who qualified for the rental assistance program (applications closed March 5) will have access to 12 months of rental assistance.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210410211545/https://cse.google.com/cse.js?cx=c0fe050eb6ce15f1d    https://web.archive.org/web/20210410213801/https://www.muni.org/Departments/Mayor/PressReleases/Pages/Municipality-of-Anchorage,-Cook-Inlet-Housing-Authority-partner-with-Alaska-Housing-to-distribute-up-to-12-months-of-rent-a.aspx
notes_H1: The public continues to be informed about Covid-19, vaccination and testing, etc. As an example:     https://web.archive.org/web/20210410215810/https://public.govdelivery.com/assets/Signup.js
notes_H2: COVID-19 testing is widely available to the public.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210410220041/https://coronavirus-response-alaska-dhss.hub.arcgis.com/app/2d92b77bc8044329a1ee3954b063bd8c
notes_H3: Alaska has a contact tracing program, though it is not clear how thorough it is.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210322232305/https://cse.google.com/cse.js?cx=c0fe050eb6ce15f1d
notes_H6: Anchorage Assembly ends mask mandate effective immediately marking a significant policy change on mask mandate termination that was originally scheduled on May 21.  Currently (May 14 Update) over 37% and 42% of Alaskans are vaccinated fully and with at least one dose respectively.    Source:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210515150017/https://www.adn.com/alaska-news/anchorage/2021/05/14/anchorage-assembly-ends-mask-mandate-effective-immediately/
notes_H7: Alaska begins Free Vaccination Campaign at three major airport for anyone traveling to Alaska for business, tourism, and other purpose.    Source:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210603194748/https://www.alaskapublic.org/2021/06/02/alaska-launches-covid-19-airport-vaccination-program/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210603194856/https://www.npr.org/2021/06/02/1002710403/alaska-lures-tourists-with-its-stunning-landscapes-and-free-covid-19-vaccine

name: Alabama
notes_C1: As of 1 June, begin to code as 0 since the Safer Apart order is no longer in effect.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210604194908/https://governor.alabama.gov/newsroom/2021/05/governor-ivey-announces-covid-19-public-health-order-and-state-of-emergency-to-end/
notes_C2: Policy last updated June 14, 2021 to include information on fully vaccinated people, which resulted in NO change to the policy.    The CDC recommendations include risk mitigation but does not recommend closures. The "Guidance for Businesses and Employers Responding to Coronavirus Disease 2019 (COVID-19)" was last updated on 31 December 2020 and also doesn't recommend closures.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210615113611/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/community/organizations/business-employers/bars-restaurants.html    https://web.archive.org/web/20210621171029/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/community/guidance-business-response.html
notes_C3: No new updates. Policy last updated 20 May 2021: "Updated cleaning and disinfection information"    The CDC "continues to recommend avoiding large events and gatherings. Currently, CDC does not provide numbers to define small and large events."    https://web.archive.org/web/20210620185116/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/community/large-events/considerations-for-events-gatherings.html
notes_C4: Continue to code as 0. As of 1 June 2021, the Safer Apart order is no longer in effect.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210604194908/https://governor.alabama.gov/newsroom/2021/05/governor-ivey-announces-covid-19-public-health-order-and-state-of-emergency-to-end/
notes_C5: No change in policy found.
notes_C6: No change in policy found.
notes_C7: The CDC states: "Delay travel until you are fully vaccinated. If you are not fully vaccinated and must travel, follow CDC’s recommendations for unvaccinated people. . . . You do NOT need to get tested or self-quarantine if you are fully vaccinated or have recovered from COVID-19 in the past 3 months. You should still follow all other travel recommendations."     On 10 June 2021, the CDC updated domestic travel recommendations with the changes in mask guidance for vaccinated vs unvaccinated people:     "Wearing a mask over your nose and mouth is required on planes, buses, trains, and other forms of public transportation traveling into, within, or out of the United States and while indoors at U.S. transportation hubs such as airports and stations. Travelers are not required to wear a mask in outdoor areas of a conveyance (like on a ferry or the top deck of a bus). CDC recommends that travelers who are not fully vaccinated continue to wear a mask and maintain physical distance when traveling."    https://web.archive.org/web/20210618031941/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/travel-during-covid19.html
notes_C8: No new updates. Policy last updated 30 April 2021.    The CDC states:   "With specific exceptions, several Presidential proclamations suspend and limit entry into the United States, as immigrants or nonimmigrants, of noncitizens who were physically present within the following countries during the 14-day period preceding their entry or attempted entry into the United States." This includes fully vaccinated people. See webpage for list of countries.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210618023101/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/from-other-countries.html
notes_E1: No change in policy as of 12 June 2021 so continue to code as 1A.    However, “Alabama will end its participation in all federally funded pandemic unemployment compensation programs effective June 19 including: the additional $300 weekly payment to recipients of unemployment compensation; benefits to gig and part-time workers who would not usually qualify; and an emergency extension of benefits.”    https://web.archive.org/web/20210611012917/https://apnews.com/article/sc-state-wire-alabama-coronavirus-pandemic-business-health-aeb664db9ad9d1d414953afd4c6f3cf5
notes_E2: On 29 March 2021, the CDC announced a 90 day extension of the federal eviction moratorium. The moratorium is effective 01 April 2021 through 30 June 2021.    The Biden Administration's American Rescue Plan does not provide any other form of explicit contract relief, so the code remains 1.    Link to CDC Eviction Moratorium:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210329145921/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/more/pdf/CDC-Eviction-Moratorium-03292021.pdf    Link to White House Press Release on continued renter and landlord support:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210329145608/https://www.whitehouse.gov/briefing-room/statements-releases/2021/03/29/fact-sheet-the-biden-harris-administrations-multi-agency-effort-to-support-renters-and-landlords/
notes_H1: No change in policy as of 11 June 2021 so continue to code as 2G. Among other things, there continues to be a frequently updated website with COVID-related information.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210611013721/https://covid19.alabama.gov/
notes_H2: As of 04 May 2021, CDC recommends testing for those who have COVID-19 symptoms and those who are asymptomatic with certain criteria. Because not all asymptomatic people should be tested (see below), I am keeping the code at 2 (open to revision).    "The following people should get tested for COVID-19:    People who have symptoms of COVID-19.  People who are fully vaccinated with COVID-19 vaccine should be evaluated by their healthcare provider and tested for COVID-19 if indicated.  People without symptoms of COVID-19 such as:  People not fully vaccinated with COVID-19 vaccine who have had close contact with someone with confirmed COVID-19 (including a person who does not have symptoms within 10 days of their positive test result).  People not fully vaccinated with COVID-19 vaccine who have taken part in activities that put them at higher risk for COVID-19, such as attending large social or mass gatherings, or being in crowded indoor settings.  People not fully vaccinated with COVID-19 vaccine who are prioritized for expanded community screening for COVID-19.  People not fully vaccinated with COVID-19 vaccine who have been asked or referred to get testing by their school, workplace, healthcare provider, state, tribal, local or territorial health department.    The following people who have been exposed to someone with COVID-19 do NOT need to get tested if they do not have COVID-19 symptoms:    Persons who are fully vaccinated with COVID-19 vaccine not living in a congregate setting.  For residents in non-healthcare congregate settings (e.g. correctional and detention facilities, group homes) and employees of residential congregate settings and high-density workplaces (e.g. meat and poultry processing and manufacturing plants), refer to CDC’s recommendations for fully vaccinated people.  People who have tested positive for COVID-19 within the past 3 months and recovered, as long as they do not develop new symptoms, do not need to get tested."    https://web.archive.org/web/20210614184511/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/testing/diagnostic-testing.html
notes_H3: No change in policy as of 12 June 2021 so continue to code as 1.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210604214204/https://www.alabamapublichealth.gov/covid19/contact-tracing.html
notes_H6: No new updates. Policy last updated 16 May 2021. "If you are fully vaccinated, you can resume activities that you did prior to the pandemic. Fully vaccinated people can resume activities without wearing a mask or physically distancing, except where required by federal, state, local, tribal, or territorial laws, rules, and regulations, including local business and workplace guidance."    https://web.archive.org/web/20210612011626/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/vaccines/fully-vaccinated.html
notes_H7: No change in policy as of 12 June 2021 so continue to code as 5G.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210605002212/https://www.alabamapublichealth.gov/covid19vaccine/

name: Arkansas
notes_C1: No changes to Arkansas’s education policies.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210531020148/https://dese.ade.arkansas.gov/Offices/communications/covid-19-information

notes_C7: The CDC states: "Delay travel until you are fully vaccinated. If you are not fully vaccinated and must travel, follow CDC’s recommendations for unvaccinated people. . . . You do NOT need to get tested or self-quarantine if you are fully vaccinated or have recovered from COVID-19 in the past 3 months. You should still follow all other travel recommendations."     On 10 June 2021, the CDC updated domestic travel recommendations with the changes in mask guidance for vaccinated vs unvaccinated people:     "Wearing a mask over your nose and mouth is required on planes, buses, trains, and other forms of public transportation traveling into, within, or out of the United States and while indoors at U.S. transportation hubs such as airports and stations. Travelers are not required to wear a mask in outdoor areas of a conveyance (like on a ferry or the top deck of a bus). CDC recommends that travelers who are not fully vaccinated continue to wear a mask and maintain physical distance when traveling."    https://web.archive.org/web/20210614180254/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/travel-during-covid19.html
notes_C8: No new updates. Policy last updated 30 April 2021.    The CDC states:   "With specific exceptions, several Presidential proclamations suspend and limit entry into the United States, as immigrants or nonimmigrants, of noncitizens who were physically present within the following countries during the 14-day period preceding their entry or attempted entry into the United States." This includes fully vaccinated people. See webpage for list of countries.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210614181209/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/from-other-countries.html
notes_E1: The IRS continues to make Economic Impact Payments on a weekly basis to eligible individuals who file a tax return.     As of 09 June 2021:   "Today’s announcement covering the most recent two weeks of the effort brings the total disbursed so far to more than 169 million payments. They represent a total value of approximately $395 billion since these payments began rolling out to Americans in batches on March 12. . . .The last two weeks of payments contain more than 1.2 million direct deposit payments (with a total value over $2.2 billion) with the remainder as paper check payments."    https://web.archive.org/web/20210614181721/https://home.treasury.gov/news/press-releases/jy0219
notes_E2: no change.    link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210419211333/https://arfreshstart.com/
notes_H1: Arkansas Department of Health continues to provide information on COVID-19 cases and vaccinations.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210606191336/https://twitter.com/ADHPIO/status/1401298352969506816
notes_H2: No change, testing is available if "If you have a fever, cough, or shortness of breath OR if you think you have been exposed to COVID-19"     https://web.archive.org/web/20210606191501/https://www.healthy.arkansas.gov/programs-services/topics/covid-19-guidance-for-getting-tested
notes_H3: No change.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210606191551/https://www.healthy.arkansas.gov/programs-services/topics/covid-19-contact-tracing
notes_H6: No new updates. Policy last updated 16 May 2021. "If you are fully vaccinated, you can resume activities that you did prior to the pandemic. Fully vaccinated people can resume activities without wearing a mask or physically distancing, except where required by federal, state, local, tribal, or territorial laws, rules, and regulations, including local business and workplace guidance."    https://web.archive.org/web/20210612011626/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/vaccines/fully-vaccinated.html
notes_H7: Pfizer, Moderna, Johnson & Johnson    https://web.archive.org/web/20210606191853/https://www.healthy.arkansas.gov/programs-services/topics/covid-19-vaccination-plan

name: Arizona
notes_C1: As of right now, the Arizona Department of Education is "requiring masks on school campuses, on schools buses and during school-associated activities by all students, faculty..."    https://web.archive.org/web/20210616210940/https://www.azed.gov/covid-19-guidance
notes_C2: There have been no changes since the previous note and "On March 25th, the governor of Arizona released an executive order that rescinded all county and city orders that enforced mask mandates, with the exception of mask mandates applied to government buildings and public transportation. Previous restrictions on businesses, such as gyms and indoor theatres, have been replaced by recommendations/suggestions.” still stands as being the most recent information.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210616211843/https://azgovernor.gov/sites/default/files/eo_2021-06.pdf
notes_C3: There has been no change in policy, and the previous note is valid. "Events of more than 50 people will no longer need the approval of local governments. These events should continue to follow safe practices and CDC recommendations, including physical distancing. This includes youth sports."    https://web.archive.org/web/20210616212150/https://www.phoenix.gov/citymanager/specialevent
notes_C4: There are no restrictions in place for this indicator.
notes_C5: There are no restrictions in place for this indicator.
notes_C6: There are no restrictions in place for this indicator.
notes_C7: The CDC states: "Delay travel until you are fully vaccinated. If you are not fully vaccinated and must travel, follow CDC’s recommendations for unvaccinated people. . . . You do NOT need to get tested or self-quarantine if you are fully vaccinated or have recovered from COVID-19 in the past 3 months. You should still follow all other travel recommendations."     On 10 June 2021, the CDC updated domestic travel recommendations with the changes in mask guidance for vaccinated vs unvaccinated people:     "Wearing a mask over your nose and mouth is required on planes, buses, trains, and other forms of public transportation traveling into, within, or out of the United States and while indoors at U.S. transportation hubs such as airports and stations. Travelers are not required to wear a mask in outdoor areas of a conveyance (like on a ferry or the top deck of a bus). CDC recommends that travelers who are not fully vaccinated continue to wear a mask and maintain physical distance when traveling."    https://web.archive.org/web/20210618031941/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/travel-during-covid19.html
notes_C8: No new updates. Policy last updated 30 April 2021.    The CDC states:   "With specific exceptions, several Presidential proclamations suspend and limit entry into the United States, as immigrants or nonimmigrants, of noncitizens who were physically present within the following countries during the 14-day period preceding their entry or attempted entry into the United States." This includes fully vaccinated people. See webpage for list of countries.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210618023101/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/from-other-countries.html
notes_E1: There has been no change in policy and states that "In order to be eligible for unemployment benefits, claimants receiving benefits from any unemployment program must complete work-search activities during the week that begins May 23, 2021, and log those work search activities when they file their weekly claims on May 30, 2021."    https://web.archive.org/web/20210525140751/https://des.az.gov/services/employment/unemployment-individual
notes_E2: On May 21st,   "the U.S. Department of the Treasury announced that it has distributed $6.1 billion through the Emergency Rental Assistance (ERA) program in less than two weeks since $21.6 billion was allocated to the program. A part of the Biden-Harris Administration’s American Rescue Plan, this $21.6 billion ERA program was allocated to prevent evictions and ensure basic housing security for millions of Americans impacted by the affordable housing challenges exacerbated by COVID-19. "    See archive:     https://web.archive.org/web/20210522172848/https://home.treasury.gov/news/press-releases/jy0193
notes_H1: There are still coordinated public information campaigns going on, such as "The Arizona Department of Education has launched a new campaign titled Ready for School AZ to help families enroll their students into public school...It will also be communicating with families directly through phone calls and texts to "rebuild trust" after a difficult school year...Hoffman also encourages parents and guardians with concerns about COVID-19 to reach out to schools directly about what mitigation plans they have for the upcoming school year."    Website/URL couldn't be archived.
notes_H2: Testing is available for the general public.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210616214546/https://www.azdhs.gov/covid19/index.php
notes_H3: At this moment, there has been no change in policy regarding contact tracing.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210616214546/https://www.azdhs.gov/covid19/index.php
notes_H6: People are being advised to wear a mask "when in public regardless of whether you feel sick or not." However, the Arizona governor has issued an executive order "prohibiting universities from mandating COVID-19 tests, vaccines and masks."     https://web.archive.org/web/20210616214546/https://www.azdhs.gov/covid19/index.php
notes_H7: There has been no change in policy and “All Arizona counties have made the vaccine available to all people ages 12+. Pfizer, Moderna, and Janssen vaccines are being distributed across the state.”    In addition, similar to face coverings, the Arizona governor has issued an executive order "prohibiting universities from mandating COVID-19 tests, vaccines and masks."     https://web.archive.org/web/20210616220030/https://www.azdhs.gov/covid19/vaccines/index.php  Other website can't be archived.

name: California
notes_C1: California continues to follow CDC guidelines in school reopenings.  Day camps and youth events must also continue to follow CDC guidance    Link: http://web.archive.org/web/20210621130805/https://covid19.ca.gov/safely-reopening/         : http://web.archive.org/web/20210621132556/https://www.cdph.ca.gov/Programs/CID/DCDC/Pages/COVID-19/COVID19-K12-Schools-InPerson-Instruction.aspx
notes_C2: Policy last updated June 14, 2021 to include information on fully vaccinated people, which resulted in NO change to the policy.    The CDC recommendations include risk mitigation but does not recommend closures. The "Guidance for Businesses and Employers Responding to Coronavirus Disease 2019 (COVID-19)" was last updated on 31 December 2020 and also doesn't recommend closures.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210615113611/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/community/organizations/business-employers/bars-restaurants.html    https://web.archive.org/web/20210621171029/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/community/guidance-business-response.html
notes_C3: while California has fully opened up, there are still restrictions in place for mega events. Mega events are described as indoor events with 5000 or more people or outdoor events with 10000 or more people.  For indoor events with 5,000 or more people, attendees must confirm proof of vaccination or negative COVID-19 status in order to attend.   For outdoor events with 10,000 or more people, it is recommended that attendees confirm proof of vaccination or negative COVID-19 status in order to attend.   In addition, CDPH's guidance for face coverings must be followed during these events.    Link: http://web.archive.org/web/20210621130805/https://covid19.ca.gov/safely-reopening/          :http://web.archive.org/web/20210621130502/https://www.cdph.ca.gov/Programs/CID/DCDC/Pages/COVID-19/Order-of-the-State-Public-Health-Officer-Beyond-Blueprint.aspx
notes_C4: while California has fully opened up, there are still restrictions in place for mega events. Mega events are described as indoor events with 5000 or more people or outdoor events with 10000 or more people.  For indoor events with 5,000 or more people, attendees must confirm proof of vaccination or negative COVID-19 status in order to attend.   For outdoor events with 10,000 or more people, it is recommended that attendees confirm proof of vaccination or negative COVID-19 status in order to attend.   In addition, CDPH's guidance for face coverings must be followed during these events.    Link: http://web.archive.org/web/20210621130805/https://covid19.ca.gov/safely-reopening/          :http://web.archive.org/web/20210621130502/https://www.cdph.ca.gov/Programs/CID/DCDC/Pages/COVID-19/Order-of-the-State-Public-Health-Officer-Beyond-Blueprint.aspx
notes_C5: Public transportation remains open but a mask is required at all times, for all individuals whether vaccinated or not.    Link: http://web.archive.org/web/20210621130805/https://covid19.ca.gov/safely-reopening/         :http://web.archive.org/web/20210621130502/https://www.cdph.ca.gov/Programs/CID/DCDC/Pages/COVID-19/Order-of-the-State-Public-Health-Officer-Beyond-Blueprint.aspx
notes_C6: As of June 15, Governor Gavin Newsom terminated the stay in place order and ordered for full reopening of the state    Link: http://web.archive.org/web/20210621130805/https://covid19.ca.gov/safely-reopening/         :http://web.archive.org/web/20210621130502/https://www.cdph.ca.gov/Programs/CID/DCDC/Pages/COVID-19/Order-of-the-State-Public-Health-Officer-Beyond-Blueprint.aspx
notes_C7: The CDC states: "Delay travel until you are fully vaccinated. If you are not fully vaccinated and must travel, follow CDC’s recommendations for unvaccinated people. . . . You do NOT need to get tested or self-quarantine if you are fully vaccinated or have recovered from COVID-19 in the past 3 months. You should still follow all other travel recommendations."     On 10 June 2021, the CDC updated domestic travel recommendations with the changes in mask guidance for vaccinated vs unvaccinated people:     "Wearing a mask over your nose and mouth is required on planes, buses, trains, and other forms of public transportation traveling into, within, or out of the United States and while indoors at U.S. transportation hubs such as airports and stations. Travelers are not required to wear a mask in outdoor areas of a conveyance (like on a ferry or the top deck of a bus). CDC recommends that travelers who are not fully vaccinated continue to wear a mask and maintain physical distance when traveling."    https://web.archive.org/web/20210618031941/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/travel-during-covid19.html
notes_C8: No new updates. Policy last updated 30 April 2021.    The CDC states:   "With specific exceptions, several Presidential proclamations suspend and limit entry into the United States, as immigrants or nonimmigrants, of noncitizens who were physically present within the following countries during the 14-day period preceding their entry or attempted entry into the United States." This includes fully vaccinated people. See webpage for list of countries.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210618023101/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/from-other-countries.html
notes_E1: California's Labor & Workforce Development Agency provides a helpful chart outlining the various forms of financial support available to Californians during the pandemic, including California supplemental Covid-19 paid sick leave. See link.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210518141339/https://www.labor.ca.gov/coronavirus2019/
notes_E2: The CA Public Utility Commission directed energy, water, and communications companies under CPUC jurisdiction to suspend customer disconnections for non-payments from April 16, 2021 to June 30, 2021. These Emergency Customer Protections were originally adopted in Resolution M4842 in March 2020. Utilities must "Suspend disconnections of customers who have not paid bills; and, create additional bill payment plan options for customers and proactively communicate with customers to enroll or sustain their enrollment in programs to manage their utility bills."    California's eviction ban is also set to expire June 30. Discussion as to whether it will be extended is still unfolding (see news article).     PUC: https://web.archive.org/web/20210603124605/https://docs.cpuc.ca.gov/PublishedDocs/Published/G000/M365/K316/365316626.PDF    https://web.archive.org/web/20210603124858/https://laist.com/news/housing-homelessness/californias-rent-moratorium-is-due-to-expire-june-30-whats-next-is-unclear    https://web.archive.org/web/20210603125116/https://www.courts.ca.gov/44660.htm?rdeLocaleAttr=en
notes_H1: California continues to send public updates daily on weekdays at the department of public health website as well as on the DPH social media pages    Link: http://web.archive.org/web/20210607091104/https://www.cdph.ca.gov/Programs/OPA/Pages/Office-of-Public-Affairs.aspx
notes_H2: Testing in California continues to be free for anyone who needs it with different testing sites available throughout the state.  In April, Governor Gavin Newsom established the California COVID-19 Testing Task Force to quickly and significantly increase the state’s COVID-19 testing capacity. The Task Force works to ensure that every Californian who needs a test can get one. The task force is co-lead by Dr. Gil Chavez and Dr. Kathleen Jacobson with the California Department of Public Health.    Link: http://web.archive.org/web/20210607091405/https://testing.covid19.ca.gov/
notes_H3: California connected is the state's contact tracing program.    Link: http://web.archive.org/web/20210607085812/https://covid19.ca.gov/contact-tracing/
notes_H6: Face covering guidance continues to be in place until June 15th when CDC guidance is expected to go into effect. Until then, the following guidance is continues to be followed.  *For fully vaccinated persons, face coverings are not required outdoors except when attending crowded outdoor events, such as live performances, parades, fairs, festivals, sports events, or other similar settings.  *For unvaccinated persons, face coverings are required outdoors any time physical distancing cannot be maintained, including when attending crowded outdoor events, such as live performances, parades, fairs, festivals, sports events, or other similar settings.   *In indoor settings outside of one's home, including public transportation, face coverings continue to be required regardless of vaccination status, except as outlined below.    As defined in the CDPH Fully Vaccinated Persons Guidance, fully vaccinated people can*:  Visit, without wearing masks or physical distancing, with other fully vaccinated people in indoor or outdoor settings; and  Visit, without wearing masks or physical distancing, with unvaccinated people (including children) from a single household who are at low risk for severe COVID-19 disease in indoor and outdoor settings    Link: http://web.archive.org/web/20210611181724/https://www.cdph.ca.gov/Programs/CID/DCDC/Pages/COVID-19/guidance-for-face-coverings.aspx
notes_H7: Everyone 12 and older is eligible for vaccination.    in addition, different incentives have been put in place to encourage everyone to get vaccinated. "Vax for the win" is California's vaccine incentive program that has set up an incentive to unvaccinated individuals to get vaccinated and receive $50 incentive card and other cash prizes. In addition, those already vaccinated stand a chance to win 50,000$ or a grand price of 1.5M     Link: http://web.archive.org/web/20210607094747/https://covid19.ca.gov/vax-for-the-win/

notes_C1: Currently, "more than 75 percent of school districts in Connecticut offer fully in-person learning, according to the state data."    https://archive.is/WTn5w
notes_C2: "Effective May 19, 2021, all remaining Sector Rules for Reopening are lifted, with certain exceptions related to mask-wearing. Unvaccinated individuals should continue to wear masks indoors, and masks are still required in healthcare facilities (hospitals, medical offices, etc.), public and private transit (airports, taxis, trains, etc.), correctional facilities, schools, and childcare.    Outdoors:  Masks not required.    Indoors:  Vaccinated individuals not required to wear masks.  Unvaccinated individuals must continue to wear masks. notes_C7: No change:   Update: "As of April 2, 2021, CDC has updated their travel guidance; since fully vaccinated travelers are less likely to contract and spread COVID-19, they can travel safely within the United States.    Fully vaccinated persons, meaning persons who are at least 14 days or more after the last dose of their vaccine series, can travel within the United States and do not have to test before or after travel (unless their destination requires it) and do not have to quarantine after travel.    Fully vaccinated persons should still:    Wear a mask over their nose and mouth  Stay 6 feet from others and avoid crowds  Wash hands often or use hand sanitizer"    For unvaccinated:   Before Travel:   Plan ahead and check if your airline or destination requires testing, health information, or other documentation.  Some destinations require a viral test 1-3 days prior to travel. Visit the Connecticut Testing Locator or call 211 to locate a testing site.  Keep a copy of your test results with you during travel in case you are asked for them.  Anyone who develops signs/symptoms of COVID-19 prior to travel should stay home and get tested.    After Travel:  Review CDC guidance for post-travel quarantine and testing  Get tested 3-5 days after travel AND self-quarantine at home for a full 7 days after travel.  Continue to stay home and self-quarantine for a full 7 days after travel, even if your test is negative.  If your test is positive, isolate yourself to protect others from getting infected.  If you do not get tested, stay home and self-quarantine for a full 10 days after travel.  Remember to self-monitor for signs and symptoms of COVID-19 while in quarantine. If at any time during your quarantine you develop signs and symptoms of COVID-19, self-isolate (including away from other members of your travel party), contact a healthcare provider, and seek testing.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210422211730/https://portal.ct.gov/coronavirus/travel
notes_C8: Last updated Apr 30th, 2021. The previous policy coding remains unchanged.     The CDC states:   "With specific exceptions, several Presidential proclamations suspend and limit entry into the United States, as immigrants or nonimmigrants, of noncitizens who were physically present within the following countries during the 14-day period preceding their entry or attempted entry into the United States." This includes fully vaccinated people.     See archive:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210523000705/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/from-other-countries.html
notes_E1: No change:     Public health emergency extended:   "on May 18, 2021, I renewed the March 10, 2020, September 1, 2020, January 26,  2021 and April 19, 2021, declarations of public health and civil preparedness emergencies and  also issued new declarations of public health and civil preparedness emergencies, which new and  renewed emergencies shall run concurrently and remain in effect until through July 20, 2021"  https://archive.is/ZxCLt      From the executive order 9P:  "NOW, THEREFORE, I, NED LAMONT, Governor of the State of Connecticut, by virtue of the  authority vested in me by the Constitution and the laws of the State of Connecticut, and pursuant  to the public health and civil preparedness emergencies declared on March 10, 2020 and renewed on September 1, 2020 and the new public health and civil preparedness emergencies declared on September 1, 2020, do hereby ORDER AND DIRECT:    1. Increase in Weekly Benefit Amount and Qualification for Lost Wages Assistance. Notwithstanding any provision of Chapter 567 of the Connecticut General Statutes to the contrary, during the weeks beginning July 26, 2020, and ending on September 5, 2020, individuals who were eligible for a Weekly Benefit Amount of less than $100.00 and had not exhausted their state regular unemployment benefits by July 26, 2020, shall have their Weekly Benefit Amount raised to $100.00, and such individuals shall be permitted to apply for Lost Wages Assistance as a result. With respect to employers who make payments in lieu of contributions pursuant to Section 31-225 of the Connecticut General Statutes (reimbursing employers), for individuals who are affected by this Executive Order No. 9P, the amount otherwise due from the employer in lieu of contributions shall be reduced by an amount equal to the difference between the individual’s Weekly Benefit Amount to be paid pursuant to this Order and the Weekly Benefit Amount which was or would have been calculated pursuant to Chapter 567 prior to this Order. The Commissioner of Labor may issue any implementing orders that he deems necessary to effectuate this order.    This order shall take effect immediately and remain in effect for the duration of the existing  renewed and newly declared civil preparedness and public health emergencies, unless earlier  modified or terminated by me."    From executive order 10:  "Exclusion of individual stimulus payments from benefit eligibility calculations: Repeats and expands the provisions of Executive Order No. 7CC, which exempted any CARES Act stimulus payments from eligibility calculations for state-provided benefits. This expands the exemption to all federal COVID-related stimulus to capture CARES Act II stimulus."    Sources:  https://archive.vn/gkjem    https://web.archive.org/web/20210307192050/https://portal.ct.gov/-/media/Office-of-the-Governor/Executive-Orders/Lamont-Executive-Orders/Executive-Order-No-9P.pdf    https://web.archive.org/web/20210307192106/https://portal.ct.gov/-/media/Office-of-the-Governor/Executive-Orders/Lamont-Executive-Orders/Executive-Order-No-10.pdf
notes_E2: No change:   "A moratorium is a temporary halt on evictions. There are currently two eviction moratoriums in place for people who live in Connecticut: The federal eviction moratorium has been extended until at least June 30, 2021."  https://archive.is/dP9QP    "Governor Ned Lamont, members of Connecticut’s Congressional delegation, and Connecticut Housing Commissioner Seila Mosquera-Bruno today announced the launch of UniteCT, a new state program to provide rental and utility assistance to qualified Connecticut households financially impacted by COVID-19.    As further detailed in the program guidelines, UniteCT may provide up to $10,000 in rental assistance and up to $1,500 in electric utility arrearage payments to landlords and utility companies on behalf of approved tenants. Tenants and landlords will be able to complete and track applications online from any computer or smart phone. Assistance will be available through a call center and at housing counseling agencies and other community partners across the state."    Source:  https://archive.vn/WbftJ
notes_H1: Notes  No change. Campaigns appear up to date.    Source:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210319095243/https://portal.ct.gov/Coronavirus/Covid-19-Knowledge-Base
notes_H2: No change.    Source:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210322041525/https://portal.ct.gov/Coronavirus/Covid-19-Knowledge-Base/COVID-19-Testing
notes_H3: No change.    "Contact tracing is the process of contacting all people who have tested positive for COVID-19 or have had contact with someone who tested positive. It is possible to be infected with COVID-19 and have no symptoms, so contact tracing is currently one of the best ways to identify and notify people who may be infected in order to slow the spread of COVID-19. Participating in contact tracing is a way to protect you, your family, and your community.    Contact tracers from the local and state health department will be in touch with you if you test positive for COVID-19, and will also call people you were in close contact with – but will keep your information protected. You will see “CT COVID TRACE” or the number for your local health department on your caller ID."    Source:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210322043051/https://portal.ct.gov/Coronavirus/ContaCT

name: Washington DC
notes_C1: No change. Variety of in-person and virtual summer programs at schools.    "DCPS’ layered mitigation strategy includes mandatory face masks for anyone in a school building, more frequent cleaning, and HVAC enhancements to increase fresh air infiltration, as well as the availability of COVID-19 vaccine for all staff and asymptomatic testing."    Source:  https://archive.vn/z4AT5
notes_C2: Most recent update March 8th.     Policy unchanged.      The CDC recommendations include risk mitigation but does not recommend closures. The "Guidance for Businesses and Employers Responding to Coronavirus Disease 2019 (COVID-19)" was last updated on December 31st, 2020 and also doesn't recommend closures.     See archive:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210605195451/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/community/guidance-business-response.html    https://web.archive.org/web/20210605164612/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/community/organizations/business-employers/bars-restaurants.html
notes_C3: As of June 1, 2021, there has been no policy change. As stated in Mayor Bowser's situational update, "Beginning on Friday, May 21, at 5 a.m., restrictions on most public and commercial activity, including capacity limits, types of activities, and time restrictions, will be lifted." This includes most public events. This will be coded as 1T until June 11, when nightclubs and large sports/entertainment venues will open.    Source:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210602210551/https://coronavirus.dc.gov/sites/default/files/dc/sites/coronavirus/release_content/attachments/Situational-Update-Presentation_May_17_2021_.pdf
notes_C4: "Just in time for the weekend, D.C. nightlife is coming back at full capacity.  All capacity limits are lifted at bars, nightclubs and music venues as of Friday.  That includes venues that seat more than 2,500 people, which previously had to apply for waivers, under an order from D.C. Mayor Muriel Bowser.    These were the last remaining restrictions in the District, but expect some safety protocols to remain in place.  Businesses, houses of worship and other organizations that serve people vulnerable to COVID-19 are free to enforce stronger safety protocols.  Businesses and organizations can ask to see proof of a COVID-19 vaccine and masks are required on public transit and in rideshares, D.C. says."    Source:  https://archive.vn/J2eFW
notes_C5: No change in code.    Source:  https://archive.vn/F8yeq
notes_C6: No change. No stay-at-home requirement but "fully vaccinated people should continue to stay home if they are sick."    Source:  https://archive.vn/5BDm3
notes_C7: No change.    "Fully Vaccinated Visitors (or visitors who tested positive for COVID-19 in the previous 90 days) may:   Travel to DC from domestic locations without quarantining unless showing symptoms of COVID-19.   If traveling from an international location, visitors must show a negative test before boarding a flight to the U.S. and get tested 3-5 days following travel.     To know: fully vaccinated is defined as 14 days after the second dose of a 2-dose series, or after one dose of a single-dose vaccine. There are additional travel guidelines for DC residents from DC Health.    Unvaccinated Visitors    You don’t need a COVID-19 test if:  Traveling from Maryland and Virginia or if you're in DC less than 24 hours    COVID-19 testing & quarantining requirements for non-essential travel:  Get a COVID-19 test 1-3 days before visiting DC  If a traveler tests positive while in DC, they must complete their isolation before traveling home, and susceptible close contacts must complete a 10-day quarantine    Essential Travel:   A test is required if essential travelers have more than 1 week of notice; limit activities in DC    To know:   Private institutions and local government officials may ask for proof of a negative test."    Source:  https://archive.vn/E7i8Y
notes_C8: Last updated Apr 30th, 2021. The previous policy coding remains unchanged.     The CDC states:   "With specific exceptions, several Presidential proclamations suspend and limit entry into the United States, as immigrants or nonimmigrants, of noncitizens who were physically present within the following countries during the 14-day period preceding their entry or attempted entry into the United States." This includes fully vaccinated people.     See archive:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210606105605/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/from-other-countries.html
notes_E1: The IRS continues to make Economic Impact Payments on a weekly basis to eligible individuals who file a tax return.     As of 09 June 2021:   "Today’s announcement covering the most recent two weeks of the effort brings the total disbursed so far to more than 169 million payments. They represent a total value of approximately $395 billion since these payments began rolling out to Americans in batches on March 12. . . .The last two weeks of payments contain more than 1.2 million direct deposit payments (with a total value over $2.2 billion) with the remainder as paper check payments."    https://web.archive.org/web/20210614181721/https://home.treasury.gov/news/press-releases/jy0219
notes_E2: No change. Several forms of debt/contract relief (eg no utility disconnections and no telecommunications disconnections).    Sources:  https://archive.vn/Ojfvo  https://archive.fo/y6xcY
notes_H1: No change. DC's coronavirus website remains up-to-date.    Source:  https://archive.vn/hWYGN
notes_H2: No change.    "DC residents, 3 years of age and older, experiencing any COVID-19 symptom (fever, cough, sore throat, shortness of breath or difficulty breathing, congestion, body aches, chills, runny nose) or with known exposure to COVID-19 should get a COVID-19 test. You DO NOT need a doctor's note for any of the walk-in sites. Testing and quarantine go together. While you wait for your results, protect our community by staying home.    Test Yourself DC is a COVID-19 At Home Testing Kit that allows you to take a COVID-19 test at home without having to wait in line at a testing site. The COVID-19 At Home Testing Kit should be used by individuals 18 years of age and older. Test Yourself DC kits are available for pick-up at 16 libraries located around the city. For more information, visit testyourself.dc.gov."    Sources:  https://archive.vn/x16Jb  https://archive.is/LTqWy
notes_H3: No change.    "This Contact Trace Force supports DC Health’s critical operation to contain the spread of COVID-19 in the District of Columbia and prevent hospitalization and death. This will be achieved through rapid and robust case identification, case investigation and contact tracing resulting in safe isolation and quarantine for all District residents. This force is designated as essential and is part of the District’s emergency response which operates seven days a week.  Work may be required during evenings and weekends."    Source:  https://archive.vn/oMDqz
notes_H6: No change.    "Residents who aren't fully vaccinated are encouraged to continue wearing masks. People are considered fully vaccinated 14 days after receiving their final shot.    Masks are still required on trains, buses, taxis and planes and in child care settings, schools,  correctional facilities, homeless shelters and transportation hubs like train stations and airports, Bowser said. Businesses and employers can still require people wear masks, so people should continue to carry masks with them."    Source:  https://archive.vn/lM8b7
notes_H7: No change.    Individuals over 12 years old are eligible. The Pfizer vaccine, the Moderna vaccine, and the Janssen (Johnson & Johnson) vaccine are being administered.    Sources:  https://archive.vn/DXAfT  https://archive.is/gpzRV

name: Delaware
notes_C1: As of June 14, there has been no change in policy. Based on guidelines posted on the Delaware Department of Education website, "the conditions for the start of school in Delaware . . . corresponds to a hybrid model of in-person and remote learning to start the year. Hybrid models of learning will look different in different districts, charters and private/parochial schools, depending on locally designed plans, developed with feedback from educators, staff, families, students, and community members." Thus, schools will be offering a combination of in-person and remote learning in the fall, and because districts can make specific decisions regarding these guidelines, this remains coded as 2T.    Source:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210606075749/https://www.doe.k12.de.us/Page/4260
notes_C2: As of June 14, there has been no change in policy. Capacity restrictions were lifted as of May 21, though residents are recommended to “follow social distancing guidance.”    Source:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210620213239/https://6abc.com/reopen-delaware-covid-19-restrictions-removing-indoor-capacity-face-masks/10671668/
notes_C3: As of June 14, there has been no change in policy. “Events over 250 people indoors and outdoors will still require plan approval from DPH to ensure compliance with basic precautions to prevent spread of COVID-19.” However, they are still allowed, so this remains coded as 1T.    Source:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210620213239/https://6abc.com/reopen-delaware-covid-19-restrictions-removing-indoor-capacity-face-masks/10671668/
notes_C4: As of June 14, there has been no change in policy. "Events over 250 people indoors and outdoors will still require plan approval from DPH to ensure compliance with basic precautions to prevent spread of COVID-19." Based on this guidance, this remains coded as 2G.    Source:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210620213239/https://6abc.com/reopen-delaware-covid-19-restrictions-removing-indoor-capacity-face-masks/10671668/
notes_C5: As of June 14, there has been no change in policy. Public transport is operating fully without restrictions.    Source:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210606081742/https://dartfirststate.com/coronavirus/
notes_C6: As of June 14, there is currently no stay at home order in place.
notes_C7: The CDC states: "Delay travel until you are fully vaccinated. If you are not fully vaccinated and must travel, follow CDC’s recommendations for unvaccinated people. . . . You do NOT need to get tested or self-quarantine if you are fully vaccinated or have recovered from COVID-19 in the past 3 months. You should still follow all other travel recommendations."     On 10 June 2021, the CDC updated domestic travel recommendations with the changes in mask guidance for vaccinated vs unvaccinated people:     "Wearing a mask over your nose and mouth is required on planes, buses, trains, and other forms of public transportation traveling into, within, or out of the United States and while indoors at U.S. transportation hubs such as airports and stations. Travelers are not required to wear a mask in outdoor areas of a conveyance (like on a ferry or the top deck of a bus). CDC recommends that travelers who are not fully vaccinated continue to wear a mask and maintain physical distance when traveling."    https://web.archive.org/web/20210618031941/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/travel-during-covid19.html
notes_C8: No new updates. Policy last updated 30 April 2021.    The CDC states:   "With specific exceptions, several Presidential proclamations suspend and limit entry into the United States, as immigrants or nonimmigrants, of noncitizens who were physically present within the following countries during the 14-day period preceding their entry or attempted entry into the United States." This includes fully vaccinated people. See webpage for list of countries.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210618023101/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/from-other-countries.html
notes_E1: As of June 14, the DE Relief Grants program is still in effect, which assists small businesses and nonprofit organizations.     Source:  http://web.archive.org/web/20210620213937/https://governor.delaware.gov/relief/
notes_E2: As of June 14, Delaware continues to have eviction moratorium in place, with DEHAP rent assistance available to those who apply. However, “DSHA is currently not accepting applications for mortgage assistance; however, funding is expected to be provided to the state in the coming weeks through the American Rescue Plan Act of 2021.” Additionally, CARES Act funding will be used to provide payments for qualified applicants in terms of rent/mortgage assistance.    Source:  http://web.archive.org/web/20210620213937/https://governor.delaware.gov/relief/
notes_H1: As of June 14, Delaware continues to provide high quality information on their website. This remains coded as 2G.    Source:  http://web.archive.org/web/20210620214151/https://coronavirus.delaware.gov/
notes_H2: As of June 14, there is no change in policy. Coronavirus testing remains generally available, though asymptomatic fully vaccinated people are recommended not to get tested.    Source:  http://web.archive.org/web/20210620214242/https://coronavirus.delaware.gov/testing/
notes_H3: As of June 14, there has been no change in policy. Delaware continues to practice contact tracing.     Source:   http://web.archive.org/web/20210620214437/https://coronavirus.delaware.gov/contact-tracing/
notes_H6: As of June 14, there is no change in policy.   From May 21, "Delawareans, visitors, and Delaware businesses should follow social distancing and masking guidance for fully vaccinated individuals issued by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC). Unvaccinated Delawareans should continue to wear masks to reduce their risk of contracting and spreading COVID-19.    The CDC guidance advises that fully vaccinated people can stop distancing and wearing masks in most places indoors and outdoors, except in certain crowded and congregate settings. Unvaccinated and partially vaccinated individuals should continue to wear masks in public settings and around those who live outside of their household. Governor Carney’s order continues to require mask-wearing on public transit, planes, in schools, health care facilities and congregate settings like prisons and homeless shelters. The order also continues to require mask-wearing in State-owned buildings and facilities, including Division of Motor Vehicles (DMV) facilities, Delaware State Service Centers, and the Carvel State Office Building."    Source:  http://web.archive.org/web/20210620215428/https://news.delaware.gov/2021/05/18/governor-carney-signs-29th-modification-eliminates-distancing-and-mask-mandate/
notes_H7: As of June 14, there has been no change in policy and Delaware continues to vaccinate residents age 12 and above.     Source:  http://web.archive.org/web/20210620214646/https://coronavirus.delaware.gov/vaccine/

Fully vaccinated people can resume activities without wearing a mask or physically distancing, except where required by federal, state, local, tribal, or territorial laws, rules, and regulations, including local business and workplace guidance."    https://web.archive.org/web/20210612011626/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/vaccines/fully-vaccinated.html
notes_H7: No new updates. The Pfizer vaccine is available for those 12 years and older (12-17 year old must be accompanied by a guardian).    https://web.archive.org/web/20210514174742/https://floridahealthcovid19.gov/vaccine-eligibility/
