name: Hawaii
notes_C1: At the end of the 2020-21 school year, based on fourth-quarter data, nearly all schools were either doing full in-person learning or blended learning, so most students have already been back on campus for some form of in-person learning over the past two months. According to the Schools Superintendent, "all HIDOE schools will be fully open for daily, in-person learning” starting Aug. 3.     During the summer months, the Hawaii Department of Education is offering expanded options for summer school as the pandemic wanes. Options include "official summer school" at school sites for grades K-12 and to option to enroll via E-school for grades 9-12., learning hubs, and specialized student learning and accelerated learning options.     University of Hawaii is in the process of updating its COVID-19 guidelines for the 10-campus system, and the campus communities will be notified when the updated guidelines are finalized. Masks are no longer required outdoors on campuses as of May 27. The COVID-19 vaccination is being added to student health clearance requirements beginning in the fall 2021 semester.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210621224430/https://www.hawaiipublicschools.org/TeachingAndLearning/SpecializedPrograms/SummerSchool/Pages/Summer-Learning.aspx    https://web.archive.org/web/20210617001447/https://www.staradvertiser.com/2021/05/18/hawaii-news/hawaii-public-schools-will-reopen-aug-3/    https://web.archive.org/web/20210622212509/https://www.hawaii.edu/news/2021/05/27/face-coverings-no-longer-required-outdoors-uh-campuses/
notes_C2: Honolulu has a new tiered reopening system tied directly to vaccination rate. The city and county are in Tier 4 and will progress to Tier 5 once 60% of the population is vaccinated (as of 6/21, 57% are vaccinated). Most sectors are open but some have capacity restrictions (ie restaurants capped at 10 occupants inside). Night life establishments are capped at 50% occupancy and guests must have a negative test or show proof of full vaccination.     On June 9 the Mayor of the city and county of Honolulu issued Executive Order 2021-08, implementing Tier 4 of Honolulu's "post covid-19 vaccine" reopening framework. The EO went into effect immediately and will be in place through July 9, 2021. Order 1 of the EO states, "All individuals currently living within the City may leave their residences to engage in  Essential Activities1, maintain Essential Governmental Functions, operate/visit Essential Businesses, or operate/visit/utilize Designated Businesses and Operations. All other activities,  businesses, and operations are prohibited. However, at this stage of the pandemic, most activities, businesses, and operations are permitted with minimal restrictions (e.g., face coverings  required in indoor shared spaces with limitations on group sizes).     The Mayor of the county of Hawaii issued Emergency Rule No. 15 on May 29, 2021. "All businesses, operations, and activities are permitted to remain open except those businesses, operations and activities delineated in Exhibit 5." Exhibit 5 includes nightclubs, large indoor venues, large outdoor venues, road races (including marathons and triathlons).     https://web.archive.org/web/20210622213232/https://governor.hawaii.gov/wp-content/uploads/2021/05/2105148-COH_Mayors-COVID-19-Emergency-Rule-No.-15-distribution-signed.pdf    https://web.archive.org/web/20210622212952/https://www.oneoahu.org/reopening-strategy
notes_C3: According to the State Reopening Strategy website, the state remains in the "Act with Care (minor disruption) impact level. The county of Kaua'i is in Tier 4, city and county of Honolulu is Tier 4, county of Maui status "act with care", and county of Hawai'i "act with care." Social gatherings are limited to 10 for indoor gatherings and up to 25 for outdoor gatherings. https://web.archive.org/web/20210622235902/https://recoverynavigator.hawaii.gov/reopening-status/
notes_C4: According to the State Reopening Strategy website, the state remains in the "Act with Care (minor disruption) impact level. The county of Kaua'i is in Tier 4, city and county of Honolulu is Tier 4, county of Maui status "act with care", and county of Hawai'i "act with care." Social gatherings are limited to 10 for indoor gatherings and up to 25 for outdoor gatherings. https://web.archive.org/web/20210622235902/https://recoverynavigator.hawaii.gov/reopening-status/
notes_C5: Based on searches, there are no measures to close public transportation. Honolulu's bus service encourages riders to limit their bus/van trips to essential travel only.    https://archive.vn/5cVSu
notes_C6: "Under the Act with Care impact level, at increased risk populations and kupuna [the elderly] recommended to stay at home."     https://web.archive.org/web/20210617004701/https://recoverynavigator.hawaii.gov/reopening-status/
notes_C7: "Gov. Ige...signed a 21st emergency proclamation related to COVID-19, which officially brings the inter-county Safe Travels program to an end at 11:59 p.m. on June 14. As of June 15, no inter-county testing/quarantine will be in effect and all Safe Travels and other restrictions will end for inter-county travel."    https://web.archive.org/web/20210608202532/https://governor.hawaii.gov/newsroom/office-of-the-governor-news-release-governor-ige-sets-additional-vaccination-benchmarks-for-gatherings-restaurants-also-signs-new-proclamation-terminating-some-emergency-provisions/
notes_C8: No new updates. Policy last updated 30 April 2021.    The CDC states:   "With specific exceptions, several Presidential proclamations suspend and limit entry into the United States, as immigrants or nonimmigrants, of noncitizens who were physically present within the following countries during the 14-day period preceding their entry or attempted entry into the United States." This includes fully vaccinated people. See webpage for list of countries.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210614181209/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/from-other-countries.html
notes_E1: On May 30 Hawaii reinstated its job search requirement for those applying for unemployment benefits (the requirement had been waived since last year at the beginning of the pandemic).     https://web.archive.org/web/20210617011607/https://www.civilbeat.org/2021/05/hawaii-reimposes-job-hunts-as-a-requirement-for-unemployment-insurance/
notes_E2: The 21st Emergency Proclamation is effective June 7 and will expire on August 6, 2021. According to a news release, "While the 21st emergency proclamation extends the eviction moratorium for those unable to pay rent, renters and landlords are encouraged to seek and accept the rental assistance relief being distributed in each county."    The Public Utility Commission issued Order No. 37667 on March 10, 2021, extending the suspension of service disconnections until May 31, 2021, and detailing steps for terminating the disconnection suspension on June 1, 2021. The Order applies to all Commission-regulated electric, gas, water, and wastewater public utilities in the State of Hawaii. By May 1, 2021, Utilities had to notify all customers that the disconnection suspension was being lifted as of June 1, 2021, with targeted communications to customers who would be at risk of disconnection. Due to this suspension, this code is changing from a 2 to 1.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210617010411/https://dms.puc.hawaii.gov/dms/DocumentViewer?pid=A1001001A21C10B42316A00665    https://web.archive.org/web/20210617004248/https://governor.hawaii.gov/newsroom/office-of-the-governor-news-release-governor-ige-sets-additional-vaccination-benchmarks-for-gatherings-restaurants-also-signs-new-proclamation-terminating-some-emergency-provisions/
notes_H1: The state's website on Covid-19 resources remains active and updated regularly.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210617011817/https://hawaiicovid19.com/
notes_H2: The County of Hawaii continues to offer mobile testing, as well as at provider sites/clinics. The city and county of Honolulu has a COVID-19 mobile testing laboratory, as well as at an airport and hotel. The County of Kauai's testing options update states that "individuals who have been identified as a close contact of a positive case are asked to contact their primary care physician, a hospital, or an urgent care clinic to schedule a drive-up test. Drive-up testing is available at KVMH, Wilcox, Kauai Medical Clinic Kapaa, and Longs Kapaa with a doctor’s order. To get a physician order: Call your primary care physician. If you do not have a primary care physician, you may call the Hawaii Pacific Health COVID-19 Virtual Clinic to be evaluated by a care provider who can order a COVID-19 test if clinically appropriate." The County of Maui is providing free Covid-19 testing for residents at Minit Medical Clinics in Kahului, Kihei and Lahaina. You do not need insurance or have to meet any criteria to be tested.     This coder found no mention of LFT testing.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210617012315/https://hawaiicovid19.com/testing-isolation-quarantine/
notes_H3: It continues to be difficult to find data on contact tracing in Hawaii that is up-to-date. The Department of Health's dashboard hasn't been updated since February 2021. https://web.archive.org/web/20210617014616/https://health.hawaii.gov/coronavirusdisease2019/what-you-should-know/current-situation-in-hawaii/
notes_H6: Governor Ige's 21st Emergency Proclamation updated the mask requirements to align with CDC recommendations- people no longer have to wear masks in all outdoor spaces.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210617005107/https://governor.hawaii.gov/wp-content/uploads/2021/06/2106080-ATG_21st-Emergency-Proclamation-for-COVID-19-distribution-signed.pdf
notes_H7: Vaccines are available to Hawaii residents ages 12 and up. 12-17 year olds are able to get the Pfizer vaccine. Pfizer, Moderna, and Johnson & Johnson are available to adults. People can register to win prizes for getting vaccinated and the state is encouraging the use of the hashtag #HIGotVaccinated.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210617015008/https://hawaiicovid19.com/vaccine/

name: Iowa
notes_C1: As of June 20, Gov. Reynolds had previously ordered that all schools in the state offer in-person learning options by Feb. 15, 2021. There is still guidance in place that recommends safety measures such as physical distancing and wearing facial coverings. Iowa universities are still offering online coursework and distance learning. However, there is no evidence of a statewide recommendation that schools close.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210621170641/https://www.npr.org/2021/02/05/964358105/iowa-sees-pressure-to-reopen-schools-but-safety-fears-persist  https://web.archive.org/web/20210621170728/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/community/schools-childcare/operation-strategy.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210621170821/https://distance.uiowa.edu/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210621170857/https://www.distance.iastate.edu/
notes_C2: Policy last updated June 14, 2021 to include information on fully vaccinated people, which resulted in NO change to the policy.    The CDC recommendations include risk mitigation but does not recommend closures. The "Guidance for Businesses and Employers Responding to Coronavirus Disease 2019 (COVID-19)" was last updated on 31 December 2020 and also doesn't recommend closures.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210615113611/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/community/organizations/business-employers/bars-restaurants.html    https://web.archive.org/web/20210621171029/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/community/guidance-business-response.html
notes_C3: No new updates. Policy last updated 20 May 2021: "Updated cleaning and disinfection information"    The CDC "continues to recommend avoiding large events and gatherings. Currently, CDC does not provide numbers to define small and large events."    https://web.archive.org/web/20210620185116/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/community/large-events/considerations-for-events-gatherings.html
notes_C4: As of June 20, the lift on statewide gathering restrictions declared by Gov. Reynolds on Feb. 5, 2021 is still in place. There appear to be no local mandates on gatherings. The City of Des Moines aligns with CDC guidelines on large gatherings particularly for unvaccinated people, which recommends physical distancing and wearing masks.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210621171245/https://www.washingtonpost.com/health/2021/02/07/iowa-covid-mask-restrictions/ https://web.archive.org/web/20210621171326/https://www.dsm.city/departments/city_manager_s_office/covid-19/index.php
notes_C5: As of June 20, there are no public transport closures or mask mandates in Iowa due to Covid-19.  https://web.archive.org/web/20190423014249/https://www.iapublictransit.com/favicon.ico
notes_C6: As of June 20, the Iowa Covid-19 website recommends staying at home when sick, as per CDC guidelines. The City of Des Moines website similarly recommends staying at home when sick. However, there are no mandates or recommendations asking the general population to stay at home.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210621163959/https://coronavirus.iowa.gov/pages/resources  https://web.archive.org/web/20210621164059/https://www.dsm.city/departments/city_manager_s_office/covid-19/
notes_C7: The CDC states: "Delay travel until you are fully vaccinated. If you are not fully vaccinated and must travel, follow CDC’s recommendations for unvaccinated people. . . . You do NOT need to get tested or self-quarantine if you are fully vaccinated or have recovered from COVID-19 in the past 3 months. You should still follow all other travel recommendations."     On 10 June 2021, the CDC updated domestic travel recommendations with the changes in mask guidance for vaccinated vs unvaccinated people:     "Wearing a mask over your nose and mouth is required on planes, buses, trains, and other forms of public transportation traveling into, within, or out of the United States and while indoors at U.S. transportation hubs such as airports and stations. Travelers are not required to wear a mask in outdoor areas of a conveyance (like on a ferry or the top deck of a bus). CDC recommends that travelers who are not fully vaccinated continue to wear a mask and maintain physical distance when traveling."    https://web.archive.org/web/20210618031941/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/travel-during-covid19.html
notes_C8: No new updates. Policy last updated 30 April 2021.    The CDC states:   "With specific exceptions, several Presidential proclamations suspend and limit entry into the United States, as immigrants or nonimmigrants, of noncitizens who were physically present within the following countries during the 14-day period preceding their entry or attempted entry into the United States." This includes fully vaccinated people. See webpage for list of countries.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210618023101/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/from-other-countries.html
notes_E1: As of June 20, there are a few food security programs in place in Iowa, including the Feeding Iowans Task Force put in place in response to Covid-19 and a summer food program for children 18 and under.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210621171621/https://coronavirus.iowa.gov/pages/feedingiowa
notes_E2: As of June 20, the Emergency Solutions Grant program is still in place, which helps prevent households from becoming homeless due to eviction, and assists Iowans experiencing homelessness to quickly regain rental housing.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210621171654/https://www.iowafinance.com/iowa-emergency-solutions-grant-cares-act-esg-cv/  As of June 20, the Iowa Rent and Utility Assistance Program is still in place, which provides eligible Iowans with rent and utility aid. However, residents of Polk County and the City of Des Moines are ineligible. The Emergency Rental Assistance Program (ERAP) serving residents of Polk County has stopped accepting applications.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210621171828/https://www.iowafinance.com/iowa-rent-and-utility-assistance-program/ https://web.archive.org/web/20210621171902/https://www.impactcap.org/housing-assistance
notes_H1: On June 7,The Iowa Department of Public Health (IDPH) has launched a multi-media marketing campaign to inform more Iowans about the benefits of the COVID-19 vaccine and encourage them to get vaccinated.    “Getting vaccinated is the best way to overcome the pandemic and get life back to normal, but it’s also a personal decision that’s unique to each individual,” said Governor Reynolds. “The goal of this campaign is to connect with Iowans in a variety of ways with messages that communicate benefits that relate to them.”    “As eligibility further expands to the pediatric population, it’s also important that we reach an even more diverse groups of Iowans, including teens and their parents or guardians, with information about the vaccine,” said Kelly Garcia, Director of IDPH. “That means getting creative with how we deliver messages through traditional and digital channels.”    Television ads and online video that are currently running feature images of iconic Iowa events and summertime traditions that reflect a return to normalcy.    A new ad features Major General Ben Corell, Adjutant General of the Iowa National Guard, who was hospitalized with COVID-19 late last year. His personal experience reinforces the message that COVID-19 can affect anyone, and that getting vaccinated is the best way to protect your health.    The campaign will run on broadcast, cable and connected TV; digital video channels including You Tube, Hulu and TikTok; traditional and digital radio channels which will include spots in English and Spanish; social media; online advertising; and billboards.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210616212002/https://idph.iowa.gov/News/ArtMID/646/ArticleID/158422/IDPH-Launches-New-Vaccination-Awareness-Campaign
notes_H2: According to an announcement by the Iowa DPH on June 16, Test Iowa will end its program on July 16. Some testing sites will close. However, the Iowa DPH is working to provide free at-home testing kits to Iowans.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210621172019/https://idph.iowa.gov/News/ArtMID/646/ArticleID/158424/Test-Iowa-program-to-end-operations-on-July-16
notes_H3: As of June 20, Iowa’s contact tracing and disease surveillance programs are still in place. However, contact tracing appears to be not as robust and focused on long-term care facilities. A news report on June 18 showed that a private lab failed to report 752 positive Covid-19 cases from May and June promptly to the state.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210621172203/https://idph.iowa.gov/Portals/1/userfiles/61/covid19/Coronavirus%20Procedures%205_7_2021.pdf https://web.archive.org/web/20210621172252/https://idph.iowa.gov/cade/idss https://archive.fo/qq49I
notes_H6: On May 20th, Iowa Governor Kim Reynolds passed a new law prohibiting counties and cities from requiring people to wear a mask. However, businesses were free to decide whether they want to enforce their own mask mandate inside their premises. This law created a confusion among Iowans as the state law contradicted the federal law on mask mandate in public transport and for unvaccinated individuals. Because federal laws supersede state laws in general, the policy is coded as 2G.    State law: http://web.archive.org/web/20210531053744/https://www.kcrg.com/2021/05/20/what-iowas-new-mask-law-means-for-schools-and-businesses/   News: http://web.archive.org/web/20210531054612/https://www.kcrg.com/2021/05/28/confusion-over-mask-mandates-forces-iowa-school-districts-to-choose-between-violating-state-or-federal-law/   CDC: http://web.archive.org/web/20210531053242/https://www.cdc.gov/quarantine/masks/mask-travel-guidance.html   CDC: http://web.archive.org/web/20210531053401/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/vaccines/pdfs/choosingSaferAct.pdf?v=1    CDC: http://web.archive.org/web/20210531053413/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/prevent-getting-sick/prevention.html
notes_H7: Beginning Tuesday, June 15, 2021 through Sunday, August 22, 2021 at midnight, Polk County will offer a vaccine lottery to help boost COVID-19 vaccination rates in the county. Individuals are eligible to register after receiving at least one dose of the COVID-19 vaccine. Once individuals are fully vaccinated, they will receive a cash prize if chosen. Every Friday ten $1,000 prizes will be drawn. Every other Friday one $50,000 prize and one $5,000 scholarship will be drawn in addition to the ten $1,000 prizes.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210621180232/https://www.polkcountyiowa.gov/health-department/2019-novel-coronavirus-covid-19/register-your-covid-19-vaccine-for-a-chance-to-win-50-000/

name: Idaho
notes_C1: On June 8, the Coeur d'Alene school district decided to relax restrictions in schools for the next school year. A news report stated: "As part of the overall guidelines for the 2021-22 school year, the district will not require face masks, will quarantine only those who are known to be positive for COVID-19 and will not contact trace or quarantine those who are not positive. A surge in COVID numbers this fall could alter that policy; however, Idaho Gov. Brad Little has made it clear during the past year that districts will be allowed to set their own policies regarding face coverings and other measures."    https://web.archive.org/web/20210614030559/https://sports.yahoo.com/coeur-dalene-school-board-votes-020200917.html
notes_C2: On June 13, business restrictions are still as per Stage 4 of Idaho's reopening:  "d. Employers should:  i. Develop and implement measures to ensure employees and customers maintain at least six-foot physical distancing from other individuals whenever possible;  ii. Provide adequate sanitation and personal hygiene for employees, vendors, and patrons;  iii. Frequently disinfect commonly touched and high-traffic areas and regularly clean those areas;  iv. Identify how personal use items such as masks, face coverings, and gloves may be required by employees, vendors, and/or patrons;  v. Provide services while limiting close interactions with patrons;  vi. Identify strategies for addressing ill employees, which should include requiring COVID-19 positive employees to stay at home while infectious, and may include keeping employees who were directly exposed to the COVID-19 positive employee away from the workplace, and the closure of the business until the location can be properly disinfected;  vii. On a case by case basis consider other actions recommended in CDC’s Guidance for Businesses and Employers Responding to Coronavirus Disease 2019 (COVID-19); and  viii. Implement additional protocols established in the Governor’s Guidelines for Opening up Idaho and the business-specific protocols published at https://rebound.idaho.gov/. "    https://web.archive.org/web/20210614031531/https://rebound.idaho.gov/wp-content/uploads/stage4-stay-healthy-guidelines-051121.pdf

notes_E1: On May 30th,  Governor JB Pritzker signed a major expansion to the Illinois rental relief program. The Illinois Rental Payment Program will provide relief for 120,000 households. In addition to the $1.5 billion for rental assistance, $400 million will be provided for mortgage assistance.    "Households must meet the following eligibility requirements to qualify:  -Household is behind on their rent for at least 30 days  -Household lives in Illinois and rents their home as their primary residence  -Household's total gross income cannot exceed 80% Area Median Income for location  -Household must have experienced a financial hardship directly - or indirectly - due to the pandemic, for example:    1. Being laid off  2. Place of employment has closed  3. Reduction in hours of work  4. Loss of spousal/child support  5. Inability to find work due to COVID-19  6. Having to stay home with children due to closure of day care/school  7. Unable to participate in previous employment due to the workplace's high risk of severe illness from COVID-19    -At risk of homelessness or housing instability"     https://web.archive.org/web/20210519181742/https://abc7chicago.com/rent-relief-governor-jb-pritzker-chicago-cook-county/10649380/
notes_E2: On March 18, 2021, the Illinois Commerce Commission unanimously approved consumer protection agreements to help electric, natural gas, water, and sewer residential customers hard hit by the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic to mitigate outstanding consumer debt and prevent disconnections before the winter moratorium on disconnections expires on March 31, 2021. Consumers struggling to pay their energy bill must call the utility to receive benefits and prevent disconnection.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210402151910/https://www.icc.illinois.gov/home/covid-19
notes_H1: On May 15th, Gov. Pritzker planned to use $225 million on COVID19 testing programs for students who will be returning to middle and high schools in the fall. The covidSHIELD saliva test will be used on campus and results are returned in 12-24 hours.     "Testing will help quickly identify individuals who are positive for COVID-19 so that people who are close contacts of that individual can be quarantined to prevent further spread. This could include exposure in school, sports, or other extra-curricular activities. The more quickly a case can be identified, the number of potential exposures to other people can be reduced, as well as the number of people needing to quarantine."    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210514223816/https://chicago.suntimes.com/coronavirus/2021/5/12/22432320/illinois-coronavirus-school-testing-vaccine-cases-deaths-reopen-pritzker-covid-19-may-12
notes_H2: The Illinois Department of Public Health (IDPH) has several mobile testing teams that are dispatched to various locations around the state each week to provide COVID-19 testing.  Anyone can be tested, regardless of symptoms or immigration status.  There is no cost to the individual for testing, but they should bring their insurance card if they have one.  However, insurance is not required.  Specimens will be collected using a simple nasal swab.  Drive-through and walk-up testing are both available at most locations.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210322190906/https://www2.illinois.gov/Pages/news-item.aspx?ReleaseID=22977
notes_H3: In Illinois, contact tracing is primarily carried out by local health department (LHD) staff. Based on contact tracing data provided by the Department of Public Health, most regions of the state have successfully interviewed at least half of all positive cases and their close contacts (positive cases: some as high as 90%; Region 11 is very low at 0.26%. Close contacts reached ranges between 44-92% across the regions).   https://web.archive.org/web/20210322191727/https://www.dph.illinois.gov/covid19/contact-tracing-data?DV=1
notes_H6: As of June 22, masks are still recommended for unvaccinated people. They are required on public transit including in terminals, in schools, day cares, health care settings and congregate settings such as prisons or nursing homes. Businesses and local municipalities may still require masks, but vaccinated people can remove their masks in most settings.    Source:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210622074734/https://www.illinoispolicy.org/illinois-reopens-june-11-but-keeps-those-masks-handy/
notes_H7: As of June 22, anyone over the age of 12 is eligible for a vaccine. People under the age of 18 must get the Pfizer vaccine. (Moderna, Pfizer, Johnson and Johnson)     Source:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210622075629/https://www.dph.illinois.gov/covid19/vaccine-faq

name: Indiana
notes_C1: As of June 7, many schools in Indiana are open, working remotely or are operating a hybrid learning model, with areas such as Marion county having tighter controls. On May 28, Gov Holcomb extended Executive Order 21-14 through June 30, at which time all current directives in executive orders throughout the pandemic will end. This is currently in effect. Gov. Holcomb also issued Executive Order 21-15 which adjusts and lifts some requirements beginning June 1. From July 1, local school boards will determine what measures or restrictions are needed in their local schools regarding the spread of COVID-19.    Source:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210601143013/https://www.in.gov/gov/files/Executive-Order-21-15-Continuation-of-Health-and-Welfare-Provsions.pdf    https://web.archive.org/web/20210607162204/https://www.wrtv.com/news/coronavirus/indianas-public-health-order-extended-to-june-30-with-some-changes
notes_C2: Policy last updated June 14, 2021 to include information on fully vaccinated people, which resulted in NO change to the policy.    The CDC recommendations include risk mitigation but does not recommend closures. The "Guidance for Businesses and Employers Responding to Coronavirus Disease 2019 (COVID-19)" was last updated on 31 December 2020 and also doesn't recommend closures.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210615113611/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/community/organizations/business-employers/bars-restaurants.html    https://web.archive.org/web/20210621171029/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/community/guidance-business-response.html
notes_C3: On May 28, Gov Holcomb extended Executive Order 21-14 through June 30, at which time all current directives in executive orders throughout the pandemic will end. This is currently in effect. Gov. Holcomb also issued Executive Order 21-15 which adjusts and lifts some requirements beginning June 1. The executive order still advises people to follow CDC advice regarding social distancing for unvaccinated people. However, Marion County still states that indoor sporting events at venues can only reach 50% and outdoor public gatherings can still only contain a maximum of 500 people.     Source:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210607162204/https://www.wrtv.com/news/coronavirus/indianas-public-health-order-extended-to-june-30-with-some-changes    https://web.archive.org/web/20210601143013/https://www.in.gov/gov/files/Executive-Order-21-15-Continuation-of-Health-and-Welfare-Provsions.pdf
notes_C4: On May 28, Gov Holcomb extended Executive Order 21-14 through June 30, at which time all current directives in executive orders throughout the pandemic will end. This is currently in effect. Gov. Holcomb also issued Executive Order 21-15 which adjusts and lifts some requirements beginning June 1. The executive order still advises people to follow CDC advice regarding social distancing for unvaccinated people. However, Marion County still states that outdoor public gatherings can still only contain a maximum of 500 people.     Source:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210607162204/https://www.wrtv.com/news/coronavirus/indianas-public-health-order-extended-to-june-30-with-some-changes    https://web.archive.org/web/20210601143013/https://www.in.gov/gov/files/Executive-Order-21-15-Continuation-of-Health-and-Welfare-Provsions.pdf
notes_C5: As of March 29, there are no policies that are directed at closing public transport.     Source:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210329224943/https://www.in.gov/indot/2436.htm
notes_C6: Original note from Rachelle Koch: As of 29 March 2021, although the CDC provides guidelines on what to consider when deciding to go out, it does not explicitly recommend staying at home. The website encourages the following:    Wear a mask that covers your nose and mouth to help protect yourself and others.  Stay 6 feet apart from others who don’t live with you.  Get a COVID-19 vaccine when it is available to you.  Avoid crowds and poorly ventilated indoor spaces.  Wash your hands often with soap and water. Use hand sanitizer if soap and water aren’t available.    Link to CDC "Protect Yourself" webpage:  https://archive.vn/nC2Yn    Additional note from Reviewer Monika Pyarali: coding updated from 0 to 1G due to further evidence of continued recommendations to stay at home on the CDC's "Travel During COVID-19" site (link to archive from Apr 1 below):      https://web.archive.org/web/20210401020716/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/travel-during-covid19.html
notes_C7: The CDC states: "Delay travel until you are fully vaccinated. If you are not fully vaccinated and must travel, follow CDC’s recommendations for unvaccinated people. . . . You do NOT need to get tested or self-quarantine if you are fully vaccinated or have recovered from COVID-19 in the past 3 months. You should still follow all other travel recommendations."     On 10 June 2021, the CDC updated domestic travel recommendations with the changes in mask guidance for vaccinated vs unvaccinated people:     "Wearing a mask over your nose and mouth is required on planes, buses, trains, and other forms of public transportation traveling into, within, or out of the United States and while indoors at U.S. transportation hubs such as airports and stations. Travelers are not required to wear a mask in outdoor areas of a conveyance (like on a ferry or the top deck of a bus). CDC recommends that travelers who are not fully vaccinated continue to wear a mask and maintain physical distance when traveling."    https://web.archive.org/web/20210618031941/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/travel-during-covid19.html
notes_C8: No new updates. Policy last updated 30 April 2021.    The CDC states:   "With specific exceptions, several Presidential proclamations suspend and limit entry into the United States, as immigrants or nonimmigrants, of noncitizens who were physically present within the following countries during the 14-day period preceding their entry or attempted entry into the United States." This includes fully vaccinated people. See webpage for list of countries.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210618023101/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/from-other-countries.html
notes_E1: On May 17, Gov. Holcomb announced the state will end its participation in federal pandemic unemployment programs on June 19.    Source:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210524183715/https://events.in.gov/event/indiana_will_end_federal_pandemic_unemployment_benefits
notes_E2: As of January 4, 2021, according to the Indiana Housing & Community Development website, the rental assistance measures using federal funds were still in effect. Source: https://archive.vn/wqJ4c
notes_H1: As of June 7, Indiana is still operating a coordinated public health campaign.     Source:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210405142551/https://www.coronavirus.in.gov/
notes_H2: As of June 7, Indiana is still running a comprehensive testing system. Hoosiers do not have to be symptomatic in order to get a test and are avialble free of charge.     Source:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210326211459/https://www.coronavirus.in.gov/2524.htm
notes_H3: As of June 7, the Indiana Department of Health is still running a comprehensive contact tracing system.     Source:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210405143159/https://www.coronavirus.in.gov/contact-tracing/
notes_H6: On May 28, Gov Holcomb extended Executive Order 21-14 through June 30, at which time all current directives in executive orders throughout the pandemic will end. This is currently in effect. Regarding masks, this order is removing the mask mandate while in state facilities, except for anyone inside any of these state government congregate facilities – the state prisons, state hospitals, Indiana Veterans Home, and the Indiana Law Enforcement Academy. Masks are also still required inside COVID testing and vaccination clinics as well as continuing the face-covering requirement inside Indiana schools through June 30.   Source:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210601143013/https://www.in.gov/gov/files/Executive-Order-21-15-Continuation-of-Health-and-Welfare-Provsions.pdf    https://web.archive.org/web/20210607162204/https://www.wrtv.com/news/coronavirus/indianas-public-health-order-extended-to-june-30-with-some-changes
notes_H7: As of June 7, anyone age 12 and older may now schedule a COVID-19 vaccination appointment. People under the age of 18 must get the Pfizer vaccine. ( Pfizer, Moderna, J&J)     Source:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210606035850/https://www.coronavirus.in.gov/vaccine/

notes_E1: On June 21,Governor Laura Kelly, in collaboration with the Kansas Department for Children and Families (DCF) and Kansas State Department of Education (KSDE), today announced the continuation of the Pandemic EBT (P-EBT) program for Kansas families who missed out on school lunches during the 2020-2021 school year.    “Expanding the P-EBT program to childcare facilities will address food insecurity and make sure all Kansas children have reliable access to healthy foods as we overcome COVID-19,” said Governor Laura Kelly. “Keeping young Kansans safe and healthy is critical, and I’m glad to see this program reaching the families who need it most.”    Through this program, P-EBT will provide a nutritional resource to families who lost access to free or reduced-price school meals and/or childcare meals due to school closures or reduced in-person attendance hours for at least five consecutive days.    P-EBT funds are being issued for the 2020-2021 school year beginning in late June 2021.    Children that attended a school that reported days missed due to COVID-19 are eligible for P-EBT. A child qualifies for P-EBT if:    They qualified for free or reduced-price meals under the National School Lunch Program, and,  The child did not receive free or reduced-price meals at school because the school was closed or operated with reduced attendance or hours for at least five consecutive days due to COVID-19.  School children do not have to be on the food assistance program through DCF to receive this special P-EBT benefit.    Additionally, children under the age of 6 in a household that received food assistance in Kansas at any time since October 1, 2020 are eligible for P-EBT benefits if they live or attend a childcare facility in an area where one or more schools were closed or operating with reduced attendance or hours.    “This year, the P-EBT benefit has been expanded to include youth in childcare facilities who were affected by the pandemic,” said Kansas DCF Secretary Laura Howard. “This program is essential to families who are experiencing food insecurity and don’t always know where their next meal will come from.”    P-EBT benefit amounts will vary by child based on that child’s learning situation. The specific benefit amount per child will be provided to the household on the approval notice received in the mail. Families will receive their benefits on a new or their existing Kansas Benefits Card (EBT Card).    For households that already receive public assistance through DCF, the P-EBT benefit will be automatically issued to the household’s Kansas Benefits Card (EBT Card). Benefits will be issued in one lump sum, staggered over 10 days in June 2021 for the months of August 2020 through May 2021. An application through DCF is not needed.  Households that do not receive public assistance must apply through the DCF self-service portal, https://cssp.kees.ks.gov/apspssp/sspNonMed.portal, using a unique identifier received from their school. The application process is estimated to start July 12.  Recipients can use their P-EBT funds to purchase eligible foods from approved retailers that accept food assistance benefits, like grocery stores and online at Aldi, Amazon or Walmart.    P-EBT for the summer months of 2021 will be issued as a supplemental benefit in the fall.  https://archive.fo/E11vo
notes_E2: As of June 13, the Kansas Emergency Rental Assistance program, announced by Governor Kelly on April 6, is still in place. The KERA program offers tenants up to 12 months of assistance with current or past due rent and past due utility and internet bills, including electric, gas, water, sewer, trash removal, and home energy services.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210614191418/https://kshousingcorp.org/emergency-rental-assistance/ https://web.archive.org/web/20210614191523/https://governor.kansas.gov/governor-laura-kelly-announces-kansans-are-receiving-critical-funds-for-housing-utilities/
notes_H1: As of June 7, Kansas is still running a coordinated public campaign through social media and through the Kansas Office of Recovery’s Covid-19 website, which offers public health information and various resources.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210614174451/https://covid.ks.gov/
notes_H2: As of June 13, testing is still widely free and available for Kansas residents. Both antigen and PCR tests are available, although PCR tests are more widely available.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210614192219/https://www.coronavirus.kdheks.gov/280/COVID-19-Testing
notes_H3: As of June 13, the Kansas Department of Health and Environment’s contact tracing guidelines are still in place.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210614192423/https://www.coronavirus.kdheks.gov/DocumentCenter/View/949/COVID-19-Disease-Investigation-Guideline-PDF---5-2021?bidId=
notes_H6: No new updates. Policy last updated 16 May 2021. "If you are fully vaccinated, you can resume activities that you did prior to the pandemic. Fully vaccinated people can resume activities without wearing a mask or physically distancing, except where required by federal, state, local, tribal, or territorial laws, rules, and regulations, including local business and workplace guidance."    https://web.archive.org/web/20210612011626/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/vaccines/fully-vaccinated.html
notes_H7: On June 23,Governor Laura Kelly today announced that 50% of Kansans 18 and older are fully vaccinated against COVID-19.    “I’m pleased at our state’s consistent progress in getting shots in arms – but we still can’t take our foot off the gas,” Governor Kelly said. “Every Kansan must get vaccinated to protect our communities, our schools, and our economy from future outbreaks, and maintain our steady return to normal.”    To date, the CDC reports that 50% of Kansans 18 and older have been fully vaccinated, and 59.9% of Kansans 18 and older have been vaccinated with one dose. Additionally, 38.5% of all Kansans are reported as vaccinated, with 46.9% of Kansans having received one dose.    “While vaccinating half of all Kansans 18 and older is a significant milestone, hospitalization rates among young people are rising nationwide. It’s critical that all Kansans age 12 and older get vaccinated,” Governor Kelly said. “Health experts continue to demonstrate a thorough, deliberate review process when it comes to vaccines, making safety the number one priority in vaccine approval. The COVID-19 vaccine is safe, effective, and free – I encourage all Kansans to roll up their sleeves and get vaccinated.”     In an effort to increase vaccinations in Kansas, the Kansas Speedway is hosting a Race to End COVID-19 event today and tomorrow, where participants will have the opportunity to drive two laps around the track and enter a free raffle drawing for various prizes.    Participants enter the Race to End COVID-19 by getting a free COVID-19 saliva test and/or vaccine administered by the University of Kansas Health System and the Kansas Department of Health and Environment. Testing is open to all ages. Pfizer and Johnson & Johnson vaccines will be available to anyone age 12 or older.    The Kansas Speedway is offering all Kansans age 16 and older who choose to be tested and/or vaccinated the opportunity to drive their personal car or truck on the track. Drivers and their riders will take two laps behind a track pace vehicle at highway speed. Motorcycles are not permitted.    The Race to End COVID-19 will be held at Kansas Speedway, 400 Speedway Blvd., Kansas City, Kansas (enter via France Family Drive, near the Sporting KC stadium across from Nebraska Furniture Mart):    Friday, June 4 from 5 to 8 p.m.  Saturday, June 5 from 11 a.m. to 4 p.m.  The Kansas Speedway is hosting the event in partnership with Wyandotte County Unified Government, University of Kansas Health System, Kansas Department of Health and Environment, and Kansas Division of Emergency Management.    All vaccine recipients will be asked to review educational material about COVID-19 vaccines and sign a consent form. After receiving the vaccine, participants will wait 15 minutes for observation for any rare allergic reactions. Those receiving the Pfizer vaccine will need to make separate arrangements for their second dose.    RAFFLE DRAWING:    Individuals that are tested and/or vaccinated will be entered into a free raffle drawing. Prizes include a set of two tickets to the Oct. 24, 2021 NASCAR Cup Series Race; a set of four tickets to the Oct. 24, 2021 NASCAR Cup Series Race; and gift cards for the NASCAR Racing Experience Ride Along.    VICTORY LAP DETAILS:    Track lap participants must have a valid driver’s license, car registration in their name, and proof of vehicle insurance. Track lap participants 16 to 17 years old with a valid driver’s license must have a parent or legal guardian in the vehicle to sign a minor release form. All track lap participants are required to remain in their personal vehicle at all times. Drivers and their riders will take two laps behind a track pace vehicle at highway speed. No motorcycles, tractor-trailers, recreational vehicles, etc., may be used for track rides.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210606141141/https://governor.kansas.gov/governor-laura-kelly-announces-half-of-kansans-18-and-older-fully-vaccinated-against-covid-19/

name: Louisiana
notes_C1: no policy change.     "Starting in the fall, all New Orleans Public School students will resume classes in person. Superintendent Dr. Henderson Lewis announced all grades will return to in-person learning at the start of the 2021-2022 school year.    After a year of hybrid in-person/ virtual learning Superintendent, Dr. Henderson Lewis said, “We’re excited that our students can once again enjoy learning face-to-face with their teachers and shoulder-to-shoulder with their peers.”  "      https://web.archive.org/web/20210601023005/https://wgno.com/news/local/nola-ps-students-will-head-back-to-the-classroom-in-the-fall/
notes_C2: No change, proclamation is effective until 23rd June.    Link: https://gov.louisiana.gov/assets/Proclamations/2021/93-JBE-2021-State-of-EmergencySigned.pdf (could not archive)
notes_C3: From 28th May new modified phase 3 rules are in effect in New Orleans. They say that "The COVID-related ban on second lines and parades will be removed and will be replaced by the traditional event permitting processes within the Department of Safety and Permits."Thus I am changing the policy value to 1G.    link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210527195804/https://ready.nola.gov/incident/coronavirus/safe-reopening/
notes_C4: In New Orleans, gatherings are limited to 250 indoors and 500 outdoors.    link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210527195804/https://ready.nola.gov/incident/coronavirus/safe-reopening/
notes_C5: no policy change.
notes_C6: People are told to stay at home if sick.    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210614191441/https://fonts.googleapis.com/css?family=Source+Sans+Pro:400,300,700,600,900|Playfair+Display:400
notes_C7: The CDC states: "Delay travel until you are fully vaccinated. If you are not fully vaccinated and must travel, follow CDC’s recommendations for unvaccinated people. . . . You do NOT need to get tested or self-quarantine if you are fully vaccinated or have recovered from COVID-19 in the past 3 months. You should still follow all other travel recommendations."     On 10 June 2021, the CDC updated domestic travel recommendations with the changes in mask guidance for vaccinated vs unvaccinated people:     "Wearing a mask over your nose and mouth is required on planes, buses, trains, and other forms of public transportation traveling into, within, or out of the United States and while indoors at U.S. transportation hubs such as airports and stations. Travelers are not required to wear a mask in outdoor areas of a conveyance (like on a ferry or the top deck of a bus). CDC recommends that travelers who are not fully vaccinated continue to wear a mask and maintain physical distance when traveling."    https://web.archive.org/web/20210614180254/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/travel-during-covid19.html
notes_C8: No new updates. Policy last updated 30 April 2021.    The CDC states:   "With specific exceptions, several Presidential proclamations suspend and limit entry into the United States, as immigrants or nonimmigrants, of noncitizens who were physically present within the following countries during the 14-day period preceding their entry or attempted entry into the United States." This includes fully vaccinated people. See webpage for list of countries.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210614181209/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/from-other-countries.html
notes_E1: no policy change.
notes_E2: Louisiana is not on the list of states which are ending extra unemployment benefits early.    link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210611095153/https://time.com/nextadvisor/in-the-news/25-states-ending-unemployment-benefits-early/
notes_H1: no policy change.
notes_H2: The Louisiana Department of Health recommends COVID-19 testing for any patients who are experiencing symptoms such as fever, cough or shortness of breath. If you have these symptoms or believe you may have been exposed to someone with COVID-19, contact your primary care physician for guidance. However, you do not have to be experiencing symptoms to be tested.    link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210614192914/https://ldh.la.gov/index.cfm/page/3934?clearCache=1
notes_H3: no policy change.
notes_H6: No change.    link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210614203134/https://www.aarp.org/health/healthy-living/info-2020/states-mask-mandates-coronavirus.html#Louisiana
notes_H7: no policy change.     Leading pediatricians from across the state and Louisiana Department of Health State Health Officer Dr. Joseph Kanter have released a public letter urging parents and caregivers to protect their eligible children against COVID-19 with the Pfizer COVID-19 vaccine. In the letter, pediatricians caring for children throughout Louisiana make the case that the vaccines are the best way for this age group to safely return to school and to summer activities like camp, and vital for the protection of families.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210520150515/https://ldh.la.gov/index.cfm/newsroom/detail/6169

notes_E1: Pandemic Unemployment Assistance (PUA) and Pandemic Emergency Unemployment Compensation (PEUC) are extended through September 4, 2021. Pandemic Unemployment Compensation, the additional $300 per week for anyone receiving unemployment benefits, according to the Michigan Department of Labor and Economic Opportunity's Unemployment Insurance Agency.   In late February, the U.S. Dept. of Labor issued guidance expanding PUA eligibility to include three COVID-19 related reasons under which an individual may self-certify when directly affected by COVID-19 including:  "Individuals who refuse to return to work that is unsafe or to accept an offer of new work that is unsafe (meaning it is not in compliance with local, state or national health and safety standards directly related to COVID-19) Certain individuals who provide services to educational institutions or educational service agencies and are fully or partially unemployed as a direct result of COVID-19. Individuals experiencing a reduction of hours or a temporary or permanent layoff as a direct result of COVID-19. The additional eligibility provisions apply retroactively to the beginning of the PUA program for those who filed before Dec. 27, 2020."  https://web.archive.org/web/20210419232201/https://www.michigan.gov/leo/0,5863,7-336-94422_97241---,00.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210419232504/https://www.michigan.gov/leo/0,5863,7-336-94422_97241_89982_92608_63224_105333---,00.html
notes_E2: Rental assistance is available for Michiganders. The City of Detroit implemented a water shutoff moratorium that is in effect until 2022. A temporary statewide ban on water shutoffs at occupied homes arising from unpaid bills is set to automatically expire on March 31. No other formal moratoriums on utility shutoffs have been issued by the state. The Michigan Public Service Commission ended other utility shutoff protections in July 2020. The Michigan Department of Health and Human Services has issued payments to the accounts of low-income customers to help them continue paying their energy bills during the coronavirus pandemic. Individuals may be eligible for utility assistance via CERA. Mortgage/Foreclosure Relief: The Michigan Department of Health and Human Services offers homeowners up to $2,000 in emergency assistance with mortgage payments, property taxes, and other housing-related items.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210419233448/https://www.michiganradio.org/post/water-shutoff-moratorium-ends-march-31-extension-possible  https://www.justia.com/covid-19/50-state-covid-19-resources/eviction-mortgage-foreclosure-relief-during-covid-19-50-state-resource/#michigan

notes_E1: On May 11, In order to address workforce shortages across the state, Governor Mike Parson today directed the Missouri Department of Labor and Industrial Relations (DOLIR) to notify the U.S. Department of Labor that Missouri will end participation in all federal pandemic-related unemployment insurance programs effective Saturday, June 12 at 11:59 p.m. (Since it is not yet in effect, this does not yet change coding.)    “From conversations with business owners across the state, we know that they are struggling not because of COVID-19 but because of labor shortages resulting from these excessive federal unemployment programs,” Governor Parson said. “While these benefits provided supplementary financial assistance during the height of COVID-19, they were intended to be temporary, and their continuation has instead worsened the workforce issues we are facing. It's time that we end these programs that have ultimately incentivized people to stay out of the workforce.”     “As I travel the state, from Sarcoxie to Hannibal and all points in between, over-arching concerns from business owners is the shortage of employees,” Lieutenant Governor Mike Kehoe said. “Across every industry, businesses cannot compete against federal largesse. Our economy is built upon an active and vibrant workforce, and we should be cultivating job-creation and employment rather than inhibiting them. The jobs exist and the demand exists, and I applaud the governor for taking this bold and decisive action.”    The termination announced today applies to the following programs:    Pandemic Unemployment Assistance;  Emergency Unemployment Relief for Government Entities and Nonprofit Organizations;  Federal Pandemic Unemployment Compensation;  Pandemic Emergency Unemployment Compensation;  100 Percent Reimbursement of Short-Time Compensation Benefit Costs Paid Under State Law; and   Mixed Earner Unemployment Compensation.   “We know that one of the last remaining hurdles to full economic recovery is addressing this labor shortage. Even with unemployment at only 4.2 percent, there are still 221,266 known job postings across the state,” Governor Parson said. “The solution to close this gap is not the excessive spending of taxpayer dollars by the federal government, but rather getting people back to work and to a sense of normalcy for themselves and their families. Today’s action ensures that we will fill existing jobs as well as the thousands of new jobs coming to our state as businesses continue to invest and expand in Missouri.”     In a letter to the U.S. Department of Labor, Missouri Department of Labor and Industrial Relations Director Anna Hui gave notice of Missouri’s intention to terminate all federal pandemic-related unemployment programs. To view the letter, see attachment.     “During the last recession in 2008, the federal government contributed $25 per week to supplement state unemployment benefits. During the latest economic downturn, Washington poured in $600 per week in addition to Missouri’s weekly benefit of up to $320,” said Director Hui.      “Even after the original $600 supplement expired, it was replaced by a federal supplement that provides an extra $300 per week on top of Missouri’s existing state benefit, meaning thousands of claimants continue to receive $620 per week or more,” Director Hui continued. “The unemployment system is designed to provide a temporary safety net as workers look to reenter the job market. Leaving the level of benefits artificially high would prevent a return to full employment in our state.”    Today’s action follows steps taken last July to require claimants to again conduct weekly work searches in order to be eligible for unemployment benefits. This work search requirement had originally been waived in March of 2020 as part of an agreement with the federal government to receive funds under the CARES Act.     Under Missouri’s law, claimants are required to perform and report three work search activities per week. Qualified work search activities include filing an application (online or in-person) with an employer or through job posting sites or attending a job fair, job interview, reemployment service, or skills workshop.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210517134411/https://governor.mo.gov/press-releases/archive/governor-parson-announces-missouri-end-all-federal-pandemic-related
notes_E2: No new updates. On 21 May 2021, "the U.S. Department of the Treasury announced that it has distributed $6.1 billion through the Emergency Rental Assistance (ERA) program in less than two weeks since $21.6 billion was allocated to the program. A part of the Biden-Harris Administration’s American Rescue Plan, this $21.6 billion ERA program was allocated to prevent evictions and ensure basic housing security for millions of Americans impacted by the affordable housing challenges exacerbated by COVID-19. "    https://web.archive.org/web/20210522172848/https://home.treasury.gov/news/press-releases/jy0193
notes_H1: As of April 17, Missouri is preparing to launch a $5 million ad campaign to urge residents to get the coronavirus vaccine. Called Stronger Together, the campaign will begin next month and will provide vaccination information through radio, TV, print and social media messages.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210417195927/https://ktvo.com/news/local/missouri-to-begin-5m-covid-19-vaccination-campaign
notes_H2: On May 28,At-home tests that check for presence of SARS-CoV-2, the virus that causes COVID-19, are now available for free to Missouri residents.     A Missourian choosing this testing option will order the free testing kit online, and the kit will be delivered to the home in two days. The kit is good for six months and comes with easy-to-follow instructions. Once the individual performs the collection by nasal swab, the testing kit needs to be returned to a FedEx collection site within 24 hours. Shipping is also free. Test results are then provided via email within two days.     This test was authorized for emergency use by the FDA.      Testing remains a key tool to keeping Missourians safe. Testing is not only for those who are symptomatic, but important for periodic surveillance especially when interacting with vulnerable populations and crowds. Many camps, events, and travel now require evidence of a negative test result before participation.    A COVID-19 test is a one-time assessment, and will only show if the individual is infected at the time of the test. For those experiencing symptoms of COVID-19, testing is highly recommended. Those who have had significant contact with someone with confirmed COVID-19 should also consider being tested.    Community testing events provide another free testing option, and these events are continuing throughout the state.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210606153442/https://health.mo.gov/news/newsitem/uuid/e78c89be-8fb6-4b29-a667-e36dfffa2999/free-at-home-covid-19-tests-now-available-to-missouri-residents
notes_H3: As of June 6, contact tracing programs for school children and congregate living are still in place.  https://archive.fo/gOY88 https://archive.fo/F9At8
notes_H6: As of June 6, Kansas City, MO still mandates that “Masks must be worn in all indoor spaces with more than one person per room, and outdoor spaces where social distancing cannot be maintained.” Since this appears to be the only mask mandate in a major city left in Missouri, coding will change from a 3T to a 2T.    https://archive.fo/gEJSp
notes_H7: St. Louis County continues to build partnerships in the community to distribute the COVID-19 vaccine. These partnerships are intended to reach into neighborhoods and gathering places so that residents can get their shots at the places they already visit. There will be a series of vaccination clinics offered at St. Louis County Library branches this summer. The event on May 26 included book giveaways and a visit from the St. Louis Metro Market, a nonprofit mobile farmers market.  https://archive.fo/IW4YL

notes_E2: As of 06 June, Montana continues to provide some forms of contract relief related to COVID-19, including its rental assistance program: http://web.archive.org/web/20210606231736/https://housing.mt.gov/Rental-Housing/Montana-Emergency-Rental-Assistance-Program
notes_H1: As of 06 June, Montana maintains a dedicated COVID-19 website with resources: http://web.archive.org/web/20210607000941/https://covid19.mt.gov/  and Gov. Gianforte continues to post updates on Twitter: http://web.archive.org/web/20210607002300/https://twitter.com/GovGianforte/status/1400964065866895361
notes_H2: As of 06 June, Montana continues to provide universal testing as resources allow: http://web.archive.org/web/20210607002304/https://covid19.mt.gov/Montanas-Testing-Information

notes_H1: No new updates. the NC DHHS website continues to provide Covid-19 related information in its website.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210604010931/https://www.nc.gov/covid19

notes_H3: Per the NC DHHS website "There are more than 1,000 full-time and part-time staff supporting contact tracing efforts at the LHD level, including the Community Care of North Carolina (CCNC) contact tracers." notes_H6: Effective May 14, 2021, Executive Order 215 eased Covid-19 restrictions, including masking policy for vaccinated individuals. Unvaccinated individuals are recommended to continue wearing masks in all settings. Coded as 2T to reflect need for all people to wear masks in certain public settings.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210607031512/https://www.nc.gov/covid-19/current-restrictions/faqs-eased-restrictions-under-executive-order-215

notes_C6: Original note from Rachelle Koch: As of 29 March 2021, although the CDC provides guidelines on what to consider when deciding to go out, it does not explicitly recommend staying at home. The website encourages the following:    Wear a mask that covers your nose and mouth to help protect yourself and others.  Stay 6 feet apart from others who don’t live with you.  Get a COVID-19 vaccine when it is available to you.  Avoid crowds and poorly ventilated indoor spaces.  Wash your hands often with soap and water. Use hand sanitizer if soap and water aren’t available.    Link to CDC "Protect Yourself" webpage:  https://archive.vn/nC2Yn    Additional note from Reviewer Monika Pyarali: coding updated from 0 to 1G due to further evidence of continued recommendations to stay at home on the CDC's "Travel During COVID-19" site (link to archive from Apr 1 below):      https://web.archive.org/web/20210401020716/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/travel-during-covid19.html
notes_C7: The CDC states: "Delay travel until you are fully vaccinated. If you are not fully vaccinated and must travel, follow CDC’s recommendations for unvaccinated people. . . . You do NOT need to get tested or self-quarantine if you are fully vaccinated or have recovered from COVID-19 in the past 3 months. You should still follow all other travel recommendations."     On 10 June 2021, the CDC updated domestic travel recommendations with the changes in mask guidance for vaccinated vs unvaccinated people:     "Wearing a mask over your nose and mouth is required on planes, buses, trains, and other forms of public transportation traveling into, within, or out of the United States and while indoors at U.S. transportation hubs such as airports and stations. Travelers are not required to wear a mask in outdoor areas of a conveyance (like on a ferry or the top deck of a bus). CDC recommends that travelers who are not fully vaccinated continue to wear a mask and maintain physical distance when traveling."    https://web.archive.org/web/20210618031941/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/travel-during-covid19.html
notes_C8: No new updates. Policy last updated 30 April 2021. This includes fully vaccinated people. See webpage for list of countries.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210618023101/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/from-other-countries.html

They represent a total value of approximately $395 billion since these payments began rolling out to Americans in batches on March 12. . . .The last two weeks of payments contain more than 1.2 million direct deposit payments (with a total value over $2.2 billion) with the remainder as paper check payments."    https://web.archive.org/web/20210614181721/https://home.treasury.gov/news/press-releases/jy0219
notes_E2: No new updates. On 21 May 2021, "the U.S. Department of the Treasury announced that it has distributed $6.1 billion through the Emergency Rental Assistance (ERA) program in less than two weeks since $21.6 billion was allocated to the program. A part of the Biden-Harris Administration’s American Rescue Plan, this $21.6 billion ERA program was allocated to prevent evictions and ensure basic housing security for millions of Americans impacted by the affordable housing challenges exacerbated by COVID-19. "    https://web.archive.org/web/20210522172848/https://home.treasury.gov/news/press-releases/jy0193

notes_H7: "Everyone 12 or older who lives, works, or studies in New Jersey is now eligible for the COVID-19 vaccine."    https://web.archive.org/web/20210620213432/https://covid19.nj.gov/pages/vaccine

name: New Mexico
notes_C1: Schools in New Mexico "are committing to offering full-time, in-person learning this fall, with some virtual learning options." There may be some exceptions.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210608230913/https://apnews.com/article/new-mexico-coronavirus-pandemic-government-and-politics-education-health-fa8e3c7a0bf35f86a6e60e765dac6f41
notes_C2: As of right now, New Mexico is still "turquoise", apart from some restrictions and exceptions.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210608222359/https://cv.nmhealth.org/public-health-orders-and-executive-orders/red-to-green/
notes_C3: The counties are still in the "turquoise" but there are limits on "entertainment venues", etc.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210608222359/https://cv.nmhealth.org/public-health-orders-and-executive-orders/red-to-green/
notes_C4: Gatherings of up to 150 people are still allowed (places of lodging, houses of worship).    https://web.archive.org/web/20210608222359/https://cv.nmhealth.org/public-health-orders-and-executive-orders/red-to-green/
notes_C5: As of right now, the transit operators in New Mexico have "resumed its full pre-COVID schedule."    https://web.archive.org/web/20210608224347/https://www.riometro.org/CivicAlerts.aspx?AID=277
notes_C6: It is advised to continue wearing masks, social distancing, and staying at home. "To fully open up now would be to favor privileged New Mexicans over our most marginalized citizens..."    https://web.archive.org/web/20210524065107/https://www.abqjournal.com/2393473/to-open-or-not-to-open-nm-that-is-the-question.html
notes_C7: The CDC states: "Delay travel until you are fully vaccinated. If you are not fully vaccinated and must travel, follow CDC’s recommendations for unvaccinated people. . . . You do NOT need to get tested or self-quarantine if you are fully vaccinated or have recovered from COVID-19 in the past 3 months. You should still follow all other travel recommendations."     On 10 June 2021, the CDC updated domestic travel recommendations with the changes in mask guidance for vaccinated vs unvaccinated people:     "Wearing a mask over your nose and mouth is required on planes, buses, trains, and other forms of public transportation traveling into, within, or out of the United States and while indoors at U.S. transportation hubs such as airports and stations. Travelers are not required to wear a mask in outdoor areas of a conveyance (like on a ferry or the top deck of a bus). CDC recommends that travelers who are not fully vaccinated continue to wear a mask and maintain physical distance when traveling."    https://web.archive.org/web/20210614180254/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/travel-during-covid19.html
notes_C8: No new updates. Policy last updated 30 April 2021.    The CDC states:   "With specific exceptions, several Presidential proclamations suspend and limit entry into the United States, as immigrants or nonimmigrants, of noncitizens who were physically present within the following countries during the 14-day period preceding their entry or attempted entry into the United States." This includes fully vaccinated people. See webpage for list of countries.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210614181209/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/from-other-countries.html
notes_E1: The IRS continues to make Economic Impact Payments on a weekly basis to eligible individuals who file a tax return.     As of 09 June 2021:   "Today’s announcement covering the most recent two weeks of the effort brings the total disbursed so far to more than 169 million payments. They represent a total value of approximately $395 billion since these payments began rolling out to Americans in batches on March 12. . . .The last two weeks of payments contain more than 1.2 million direct deposit payments (with a total value over $2.2 billion) with the remainder as paper check payments."    https://web.archive.org/web/20210614181721/https://home.treasury.gov/news/press-releases/jy0219
notes_E2: New Mexico is not required to compensate businesses for shutdown.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210608232715/https://www.santafenewmexican.com/news/local_news/new-mexico-supreme-court-state-not-required-to-compensate-businesses-for-shutdown/article_9e99bc82-c7b5-11eb-9439-df80ebe5961a.html
notes_H1: Campaign continues. New policies being made (new public health law).    https://web.archive.org/web/20210608233316/https://www.sfreporter.com/news/morningword/2021/06/03/all-nm-counties-turn-turquoisesome-with-a-little-help/
notes_H2: Available with no restrictions.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210608233729/https://cvprovider.nmhealth.org/directory.html
notes_H3: Contact tracing should be used to contain COVID and "prevent further spread of the disease. In addition, no policy change.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210606154935/https://cvmodeling.nmhealth.org/public-health-gating-criteria-for-reopening-nm/contact-tracing-and-isolation-capacity/
notes_H6: "No longer need to wear masks indoors or outside in most cases, under a revised public health order issued Friday." There may be some restrictions and exceptions.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210608234531/https://www.usnews.com/news/best-states/new-mexico/articles/2021-05-14/new-mexico-relaxes-mask-rules-for-the-fully-vaccinated
notes_H7: Over 16 are now eligible for vaccines.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210608234825/https://cv.nmhealth.org/covid-vaccine/
