Clark and Washoe) are still providing programs that may provide housing payment assistance (albeit with waitlists).    https://web.archive.org/web/20210515022524/https://housing.nv.gov/Resources/COVID-19/Renter_Assistance/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210526040619/https://chap.clarkcountynv.gov/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210617003731/https://www.renoha.org/chap/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210617003815/https://nvrural.org/renter-services/covid/
notes_H1: State-wide coordinated public campaign continues.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210606160045/https://nvhealthresponse.nv.gov/current-status-mitigation-measures/
notes_H2: Broad testing policy remains in place.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210606160018/https://nvhealthresponse.nv.gov/find-covid-19-testing-in-nevada/
notes_H3: Limited contact tracing program involving the COVID Trace app continues.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210606160108/https://nvhealthresponse.nv.gov/covidtrace/
notes_H6: As of May 3, 2021:    "Effective immediately, individuals not exempted by Directive 024, Directive 028, or guidance issued by the Nevada Health Response shall be required to cover their nose and mouth with a mask or face covering in a manner consistent with current guidance issued by the CDC, and any subsequent guidance issued by the CDC."  "[F]ully vaccinated people should continue to wear a mask that fits snugly against the sides of your face and does not have gaps, cover coughs and sneezes, wash hands often, and follow any applicable workplace or school guidance." No updates since then as of June 17, 2021     https://web.archive.org/web/20210617001408/https://nvhealthresponse.nv.gov/state-information/governor-directives-and-declarations/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210610143925/https://nvhealthresponse.nv.gov/wp-content/uploads/2021/05/5.3.21-Emergency-Directive-045-Guidance.pdf
notes_H7: On April 5th, the vaccine appointments were made available to all individuals 12 and older in Nevada. Coded as a 5 due to universal availability. No changes in policy as of June 17, 2021     https://web.archive.org/web/20210617005355/https://www.immunizenevada.org/county-specific-covid-19-vaccine-sites

name: New York
notes_C1: NY State Education Department is continuing to allow families to opt into online or in-person learning for the duration of the 2020-2021 school year. As for universities, they will also be allowed to continue their distanced learning formats if they so choose into the 2021-2022 school year.    In order for someone to return to in-person learning, they must submit the consent form for in-school COVID-19 testing. Any student in grade 1 or higher returning to school buildings must submit a consent form for COVID-19 testing in school by their first day back in school buildings. Mandatory in-school testing will happen weekly for a random selection of staff and students in all reopened school buildings.    Sources:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210621164807/https://www.schools.nyc.gov/school-life/health-and-wellness/coronavirus-update     https://web.archive.org/web/20210621164849/http://www.nysed.gov/common/nysed/files/dsted-flex-memo-2021-2022.pdf
notes_C2: "Businesses are authorized to require masks and six feet of social distancing for employees and/or patrons within their establishments OR adhere to CDC guidance, which advises that fully vaccinated individuals do not need to wear masks or be socially distanced, but unvaccinated individuals must continue to wear masks and be socially distanced in most settings.""    There are different requirements for businesses that do not congregate patrons and/or that operate below the State's social gathering limit of 250 indoors or 500 outdoors versus businesses that congregate patrons and operate above the State's social gathering limit. These requirements are outlined in the archived source below.    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210621165648/https://www.governor.ny.gov/sites/default/files/2021-05/NYS_CDCGuidance_Summary.pdf
notes_C3: "Large events requiring a city events permit will be canceled through September 30th." Outdoor sporting events and other activities through businesses that have been predetermined are subject to different rules visible through the C2 policy updates.    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210621165827/https://www1.nyc.gov/events/events-filter.html
notes_C4: "As of May 19, the State's social gathering limits are 250 attendees indoors and 500 attendees outdoors."    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210621165648/https://www.governor.ny.gov/sites/default/files/2021-05/NYS_CDCGuidance_Summary.pdf
notes_C5: State measures for reopening public transport are in place; no substantial reductions in service due to COVID. The archived source below highlights the mandatory and recommended guidelines for physical distancing; protective equipment; hygiene, cleaning, and disinfection; communication; and screening.    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210621170304/https://www.governor.ny.gov/sites/default/files/atoms/files/PublicTransportationSummaryGuidance.pdf
notes_C6: There are stay-at-home requirements for individuals who are symptomatic.    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210621170729/https://coronavirus.health.ny.gov/covid-19-travel-advisory
notes_C7: "Asymptomatic travelers entering New York from another country, U.S. state, or territory are no longer required to test or quarantine as of April 10, 2021. Quarantine, consistent with the CDC recommendations, is still recommended for all travelers who are not fully vaccinated or have not recovered from laboratory confirmed COVID-19 during the previous 3 months. Symptomatic travelers must immediately self-isolate and contact the local health department or their healthcare providers to determine if they should seek COVID-19 testing."    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210621170729/https://coronavirus.health.ny.gov/covid-19-travel-advisory
notes_C8: No new updates. Policy last updated 30 April 2021.    The CDC states:   "With specific exceptions, several Presidential proclamations suspend and limit entry into the United States, as immigrants or nonimmigrants, of noncitizens who were physically present within the following countries during the 14-day period preceding their entry or attempted entry into the United States." This includes fully vaccinated people. See webpage for list of countries.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210618023101/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/from-other-countries.html
notes_E1: "The New York State Emergency Rental Assistance Program (ERAP) will provide significant economic relief to help low and moderate-income households at risk of experiencing homelessness or housing instability by providing rental arrears, temporary rental assistance and utility arrears assistance.""    ""Most employees will get financial compensation by using a combination of benefits, which may include new employer-provided paid sick leave (depending on the size of the employer), Paid Family Leave and disability benefits. These benefits are not available to employees who are able to work through remote access or other means.    Paid Family Leave may also be used to care for a family member who has contracted COVID-19, which may qualify as a serious health condition."    Sources:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210621171422/https://paidfamilyleave.ny.gov/COVID19     https://web.archive.org/web/20210621171450/https://otda.ny.gov/programs/emergency-rental-assistance/
notes_E2: The archived source below is a COVID-19 application for the suspension of debt collection activity. It is intended "for persons or businesses that owe (non-medical and non-student*) debts to the State of New York that have been referred to the Office of the Attorney General for collection and litigation. Any such person or business or their dependents, that have been financially impacted by COVID-19, or the international, national, and state responses designed to prevent its spread, may complete and submit this application to be considered for certain forms of relief, including relief from collection activity, interest accrual, and the assessment of collection fees."    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210621171942/https://ag.ny.gov/covid-19-debt-suspension-application
notes_H1: The NY government Health Department's website offers a comprehensive public information campaign.    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210621172318/https://www.health.ny.gov/
notes_H2: "If you have symptoms of COVID-19, it’s important to get tested and isolate until you know your results.    If you have been in contact with someone who has COVID-19, get tested and stay home and away from others for 14 days.    If you go to a test site run by New York State, you will not be charged for your test.    If you go to a test site operated by local governments, private companies including pharmacies and medical practices or not-for-profit organizations, check with the testing site and your insurer to make sure there isn’t a fee for the test.     If you are uninsured, you are advised to ask the testing site if you will be responsible for any fees associated with your test. Under the federal Families First Coronavirus Response Act (FFCRA), the Paycheck Protection Program and Health Care Enhancement Act (PPPHCEA), and the Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security (CARES), a testing site can receive reimbursement for fees associated with testing uninsured individuals.    New York State has aggressively expanded COVID-19 diagnostic testing capacity."    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210621172813/https://coronavirus.health.ny.gov/covid-19-testing
notes_H3: "New York State has partnered with Bloomberg Philanthropies, Johns Hopkins Bloomberg School of Public Health and Vital Strategies to create the NYS Contact Tracing Program, a nation-leading initiative to help slow the spread of COVID-19 and make it safer to begin to return to normal again.    Contact Tracers work with people who have tested positive for COVID-19 to identify people they have had contact with and let them know they may have been exposed to the disease."    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210621173011/https://coronavirus.health.ny.gov/new-york-state-contact-tracing
notes_H6: "Given that the CDC has advised that fully vaccinated individuals do not need to wear masks and over 52 percent of New Yorkers over the age of 18 are fully vaccinated, the State will authorize businesses to continue to require masks for all in their establishments, consistent with the CDC guidance. In most settings, vaccinated individuals will not be required to wear a mask. Unvaccinated individuals, under both CDC and state guidance must wear masks in all public settings."     Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210621173142/https://www.governor.ny.gov/news/governor-cuomo-announces-new-york-state-adopt-new-cdc-guidance-mask-use-and-social-distancing
notes_H7: "All individuals 12 years of age and older that reside in the United States are eligible to receive the vaccine.    Walk-in appointments are also accepted at New York State mass vaccination sites for all eligible individuals.    Yes. The COVID-19 vaccines will be available at no cost. "    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210621173854/https://covid19vaccine.health.ny.gov/frequently-asked-questions-0

Unvaccinated individuals are at a significantly higher risk of getting COVID-19 and suffering its devastating toll. As such, unvaccinated individuals should continue to protect themselves using mitigation measures, such as masking and social  distancing...... name: Pennsylvania
notes_C1: No change.    "Not everyone will get the benefit of the early lifting of restrictions. The change will not affect high school graduation ceremonies for the Philadelphia School District, which were already planned for dates between June 9 and 11 with a limited number of tickets for each graduate.    'The events have already been planned out,' said Monica Lewis, a district spokesperson. 'At this point, we’re not making any changes.'    School ends June 11 for district students, and there will be no changes to in-person classes before the end of the year, she said."    Source:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210612171617/https://www.inquirer.com/health/coronavirus/philadelphia-covid-restrictions-lift-june-masks-20210528.html
notes_C2: Most recent update March 8th.     Policy unchanged.      The CDC recommendations include risk mitigation but does not recommend closures. The "Guidance for Businesses and Employers Responding to Coronavirus Disease 2019 (COVID-19)" was last updated on December 31st, 2020 and also doesn't recommend closures.     See archive:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210605195451/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/community/guidance-business-response.html    https://web.archive.org/web/20210605164612/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/community/organizations/business-employers/bars-restaurants.html
notes_C3: The policy was updated on May 20th: "Updated cleaning and disinfection information"    The policy coding remains unchanged.     The CDC "continues to recommend avoiding large events and gatherings. Currently, CDC does not provide numbers to define small and large events."    See archive:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210607003740/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/community/large-events/considerations-for-events-gatherings.html
notes_C4: "For the first time in 15 months, Pennsylvania is no longer operating under a COVID-19 emergency declaration.    Using its newly expanded emergency powers, the GOP-controlled Legislature voted to end Gov. Tom Wolf's pandemic disaster declaration this week. With a 30-20 Senate vote and 121-81 House vote, Wolf has no power to veto the resolution."    Source:  https://archive.is/jAIyw    "As of 12:01 a.m. Friday, June 11, Philadelphia has lifted its final two COVID restrictions: the indoor mask mandate as well as the 11 p.m. last call for restaurants.  The lifted restrictions apply to fully vaccinated city residents. Officials still strongly urge everyone to become fully vaccinated and to take precautions if not vaccinated.  Masks must still be worn indoors in select settings, including, but not limited to, health care institutions and events such as vaccine clinics and blood drives, prisons, shelters, adult day programs, trains, buses, taxis, rideshare vehicles, indoor schools, camps and early childhood education."    Source:  https://archive.vn/fp4vK
notes_C5: "The changes won’t alter SEPTA’s plans, either: Rider capacity limits on all buses, trains, and trolleys were already set to be lifted on June 1."    Source:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210612171617/https://www.inquirer.com/health/coronavirus/philadelphia-covid-restrictions-lift-june-masks-20210528.html
notes_C6: "For the first time in 15 months, Pennsylvania is no longer operating under a COVID-19 emergency declaration.    Using its newly expanded emergency powers, the GOP-controlled Legislature voted to end Gov. Tom Wolf's pandemic disaster declaration this week. With a 30-20 Senate vote and 121-81 House vote, Wolf has no power to veto the resolution."    Source:  https://archive.is/jAIyw
notes_C7: The CDC states:   If vaccinated "You do NOT need to get tested or self-quarantine if you are fully vaccinated or have recovered from COVID-19 in the past 3 months. You should still follow all other travel recommendations." and recommends wearing masks/social distancing while traveling.     If unvaccinated to be tested prior, adhere to social distancing/mask-wearing, and self-quarantining/testing following travel.     See archive:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210607003622/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/travel-during-covid19.html
notes_C8: Last updated Apr 30th, 2021. The previous policy coding remains unchanged.     The CDC states:   "With specific exceptions, several Presidential proclamations suspend and limit entry into the United States, as immigrants or nonimmigrants, of noncitizens who were physically present within the following countries during the 14-day period preceding their entry or attempted entry into the United States." This includes fully vaccinated people.     See archive:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210606105605/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/from-other-countries.html
notes_E1: No change.    Source:  https://archive.vn/uiigI
notes_E2: No change. Mostly only federal protections in place, such as federal eviction moratorium/mortgage forbearance.    Source:  https://archive.vn/GDY8j
notes_H1: No change in code. Campaigns up-to-date.    Source:  https://archive.vn/kzQC1
notes_H2: No change.     "Individuals who have been in close contact with a confirmed COVID-19 case should be tested regardless of the presence of symptoms. Close contacts are people who have been within 6 feet of a person with a confirmed COVID-19 infection for at least 15 minutes. You will need to quarantine for 10 days after your last exposure to an infected person or a 7 day quarantine with a negative test on or after day 5 of quarantine."    "What are the types of tests?    1. Diagnostic Tests  Assesses the presence of the virus at a given point in time. A negative means only that an individual was negative at the time the test.    Polymerase Chain Reaction (PCR) Tests and Nucleic Acid Amplification Testing:  Detects the RNA genetic material in the COVID-19 virus and are often collected via nasal pharyngeal; mid turbinate; nasal, oral or throat swab; or saliva collection.  Antigen Tests: Not currently widely utilized. Detects the presence of COVID-19 specific protein particles and is collected via a respiratory sample.    2. Non-Diagnostic Tests    Serology (Antibody) Tests: Detect antibodies in the blood indicating possible prior exposure to COVID-19, which may develop 6-14 days after infection."    Source:  https://archive.vn/EopQc
notes_H3: No change.    "If you test positive, a public health staff member will try to call you within 24 to 48 hours of receiving the test result. They will conduct a case investigation or share a Connect & Protect Form and collect the people and places you come in contact with while you were infectious. While you isolate for a minimum of ten days, contact tracers will reach out to your close contacts to inform them that they were exposed, educate them on what to do and provide supports and testing information as necessary for the situation. Contact tracers will not use your name when reaching out to your close contacts. Your information will stay confidential."    Source:  https://archive.vn/d9Dh8
notes_H6: Loosening of restrictions only in Philadelphia:  "As of 12:01 a.m. Friday, June 11, Philadelphia has lifted its final two COVID restrictions: the indoor mask mandate as well as the 11 p.m. last call for restaurants.  The lifted restrictions apply to fully vaccinated city residents. Officials still strongly urge everyone to become fully vaccinated and to take precautions if not vaccinated.  Masks must still be worn indoors in select settings, including, but not limited to, health care institutions and events such as vaccine clinics and blood drives, prisons, shelters, adult day programs, trains, buses, taxis, rideshare vehicles, indoor schools, camps and early childhood education."    Source:  https://archive.vn/fp4vK
notes_H7: A, B, C:    Pfizer, Moderna, and J&J are being administered. All Pennsylvanians over 12 are eligible.    Sources:  https://archive.vn/38sz5  https://archive.vn/4Sowq

name: Rhode Island
notes_C1: As of 21 June 2021, no evidence has been found to suggest a deviation away from schools in Rhode Island remaining open for in-person or blended learning. As per the guidance for Rhode Island schools, face coverings are required for all staff and K-12 students, at all times, even in stable group settings, and even when socially distanced.    Back2School RI website:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210621171037/https://www.back2schoolri.com/    RI schools guidance:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210621171135/https://www.ride.ri.gov/Portals/0/Uploads/Documents/COVID19/HealthandSafetyReopeningGuidance.pdf?ver=2021-03-10-110839-843
notes_C2: Effective 18 June 2021, in EO 21-68, Governor Daniel McKee encouraged establishments to remain vigilant.    - All businesses, organizations, operations, and government establishments must comply with applicable executive orders and RIDOH's regulations, including, but not limited to, requirements for screening individuals, wearing masks or cloth face coverings, posting appropriate signs and notices and other health and safety protocols, as well as review the guidance posted at https://ReopeningRI.com.    - All businesses, organizations, operations, and governmental establishments shall remind indoor on-site individuals who are not fully vaccinated to wear masks or cloth face coverings. A person is considered fully vaccinated if the person has received all recommended dose(s) of a COVID-19 vaccine authorized by FDA or WHO and at least 14 days have elapsed since the administration of the final dose    Additionally, EO 21-55 remains in effect - Working from home remains an effective arrangement to reduce work-related spread among employees. Office-based businesses may operate up to 80% of office capacity.    EO 21-68:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210621165530/https://governor.ri.gov/documents/orders/Executive-Order-21-68.pdf    EO 21-55:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210621170326/https://governor.ri.gov/documents/orders/Executive-Order-21-55.pdf
notes_C3: As of 21 June 2021, EO 21-55 remains in effect.    - Subject to compliance with applicable requirements such as masking, venues of assembly, including convention centers, concert halls, performance venues, spectator sporting event venues and theaters may operate up to 80% of regular venue capacity with a cap of 500 people indoors. Any event operation with more than 2,500 people is subject to the submission of a detailed COVID-19 control plan to the Department of Business Regulation (DBR) for its pre-approval, applicable municipal pre-approval, and other such requirements (including pre-event testing, maximum capacity, cap of attendees, etc.) as may be specified by DBR and/or the applicable municipality.  - Religious and faith-based organizations may conduct in-person activities up to 80% percent of worship space capacity, the guidelines for religious and faith-based organizations which are available at https://ReopeningRI.com.    EO 21-55:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210621170326/https://governor.ri.gov/documents/orders/Executive-Order-21-55.pdf
notes_C4: As of 21 June 2021, EO 21-55 remains in effect.    The following gathering restrictions are in place:    - Attendance at all indoor public and private social gatherings, parties and celebrations shall be limited to 25 people. Notwithstanding these restrictions, indoor catered events with licensed catering on site or in a restaurant may have up to 80% of regular seating capacity with a cap of 200 people, provided the responsible parties, which include event hosts, organizers, venue operators and vendors ("Responsible Parties") confirm that pre-event testing is conducted for student celebrations, including proms, graduations and other similar events, follow restaurant rules and designate a point of contact for RIDOH's case investigation.    - Attendance at all outdoor public and private social gatherings shall be limited to 75 people. Notwithstanding these restrictions, outdoor catered events with licensed catering on site or in a restaurant may have up to 500 people, provided Responsible Parties confirm that pre-event testing is conducted for student celebrations, including proms, graduations and other similar events, follow restaurant rules and designate a point of contact for RIDOH's case investigation.    EO 21-55:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210621170326/https://governor.ri.gov/documents/orders/Executive-Order-21-55.pdf
notes_C5: As of 21 June 2021, no evidence has been found for amendments to public transportation services in Rhode Island. Executive orders, press releases and news articles have been searched.    Rhode Island Public Transit Authority states that face masks are required to be worn at all times and social distancing should be observed.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210621170530/https://www.ripta.com/covid-19/
notes_C6: As of 21 June 2021, EO 21-55 remains in effect (protecting your household order).    Working from home remains an effective arrangement to reduce work-related spread among employees.     EO 21-55:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210621170326/https://governor.ri.gov/documents/orders/Executive-Order-21-55.pdf
notes_C7: Effective 18 June 2021, in EO 21-68, Governor Daniel McKee amended restrictions on internal movement.    Any person coming to Rhode Island for a non-work-related purpose from locations with a high community spread rate as set forth on a list maintained by RIDOH at https://covid.ri.gov/ must immediately self-quarantine for 10 days unless one of the following exemptions applies:    a. the person obtains a negative COVID-19 test result from a specimen taken after arrival in Rhode Island; or  b. the person (i) has received all recommended dose(s) of a COVID-19 vaccine authorized by FDA or WHO at least 14 days prior to the date of the person's arrival in Rhode Island and (ii) is asymptomatic upon arrival in Rhode Island; or  c. the person (i) was previously diagnosed with COVID-19, (ii) had COVID-19 symptoms, the onset of which occurred no more than 90 days prior to the date of the person's arrival in Rhode Island, (iii) completed the isolation requirement in accordance with Executive Order 21-26 or its successor, and (iv) is asymptomatic upon arrival in Rhode Island; or  d. the person (i) was tested positive for COVID-19 from a specimen taken no more than 90 days prior to the date of the person's arrival in Rhode Island, (ii) had no COVID-19 symptoms previously, (iii) completed the isolation requirement in accordance with Executive Order 21-26 or its successor, and (iv) is asymptomatic upon arrival in Rhode Island; or  e. the person has a negative COVID-19 test result from a specimen taken no more than 72 hours prior to arrival in Rhode Island.    EO 21-68:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210621165530/https://governor.ri.gov/documents/orders/Executive-Order-21-68.pdf
notes_C8: No new updates. Policy last updated 30 April 2021.    The CDC states:   "With specific exceptions, several Presidential proclamations suspend and limit entry into the United States, as immigrants or nonimmigrants, of noncitizens who were physically present within the following countries during the 14-day period preceding their entry or attempted entry into the United States." This includes fully vaccinated people. See webpage for list of countries.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210618023101/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/from-other-countries.html
notes_E1: As of 21 June 2021, there has been no change identified for income support.     Those who have been laid off due to the pandemic may be eligible for the state's unemployment insurance. If individuals are an independent contractor, gig worker, self-employed, or a small business owner, they must apply for Pandemic Unemployment Assistance.    It remains unclear whether this support provides <50% or >50% of the lost income. Coding as 1F, however this may not reflect the situation on the ground.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210621165008/https://dlt.ri.gov/ui/faq/
notes_E2: As of 21 June 2021, the winter moratorium on utilities remains in effect.     This moratorium is due to expire on 25 June 2021.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210621164844/https://www.providenceri.gov/pema/covid-19-housing-resource-guide/
notes_H1: As of 21 June 2021, Rhode Island's Department of Health continues to provide information pertaining to the COVID-19 response within the state via the RIDOH COVID-19 website.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210621164753/https://covid.ri.gov/
notes_H2: As of 21 June 2021, there is no detected change in Rhode Island's testing policy.    Aside from continued scaling back of testing sites, widespread lateral flow testing remains available to everyone (including asymptomatic people). All positive LFTs will be followed up by a PCR test.    Following lateral flow testing, the Rhode Island Department of Health (RIDOH) recommends follow-up PCR testing if:  - You have symptoms and get a negative result on your rapid antigen test.  - You do not have symptoms and get a positive result on your rapid antigen test.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210621164245/https://covid.ri.gov/testing  https://web.archive.org/web/20210621164103/https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1ZPU7c3QYweLDNa2TyCng_L5TC33CT_4xJrGEI_QrxSU/edit
notes_H3: As of 21 June 2021, no evidence has been identified to suggest a deviation away from comprehensive contact tracing in Rhode Island. Executive orders, press releases and news articles have been searched.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210621163924/https://covid.ri.gov/covid-19-prevention/contact-tracing
notes_H6: Effective 18 June 2021, in EO 21-69, Governor Daniel McKee amended the exemptions for mask/face coverings:    Any person, whether indoors or outdoors, shall cover their mouth and nose with a mask or cloth face covering, with the following exceptions:    a. No person shall be required to wear a mask or cloth face covering (i) who is under two years of age, (ii) whose health would be damaged thereby, or (iii) who is developmentally unable to comply, including young children who may not be able to effectively wear a mask or cloth face covering.    b. Any person who has received all recommended dose(s) of a COVID-19 vaccine authorized by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration or World Health Organization and at least 14 days have elapsed since the administration of the final dose ("fully vaccinated") is not required to wear a mask or cloth face covering, except as otherwise required by this Executive Order and other applicable state or federal laws or regulations.    c. A mask or cloth face covering is not required for any person when:  • Consuming food or drink;  • A face covering would impede communication by or with a person who has a hearing impediment;  • Working alone in an office or at a job site, or when workers can easily, continuously, and measurably maintain three feet of distance in a workplace;  • Speaking at a live interview or to a live audience when no person is within six feet of the person speaking;  • In a vehicle alone or with members of the same household;  • Undergoing a medical or dental procedure; or  • Outdoors.    - All persons must continue to wear masks or cloth face coverings on public transport and in taxis.    EO 21-69:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210621163639/https://governor.ri.gov/documents/orders/Executive-Order-21-69.pdf
notes_H7: As of 21 June 2021, all individuals aged 16 and above remain eligible for vaccination in Rhode Island. Free walk-ins are now available at many sites.    The Moderna, Pfizer and J&J vaccines are being administered.     Moderna and J&J vaccines are only administered to individuals aged 18 and above.     Additionally, individuals age 12 and above are eligible for the Pfizer vaccine.    Vaccine eligibility:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210621162955/https://covid.ri.gov/vaccination    Rhode Island COVID vaccine FAQ:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210621163034/https://covid.ri.gov/vaccination/covid-19-vaccine-faqs

name: South Carolina
notes_C1: All primary and secondary schools are utilizing face to face instruction. According to the latest SC DHEC interim guidance for School Operations (updated on 20 May 2021), schools providing in-person instruction should prioritize mask use, physical distancing, and other measures to prevent the spread of COVID-19.    The University of South Carolina plans to return to full capacity, in-person learning in Fall 2021, and recommends social distancing. In addition, "unvaccinated students will wear face coverings in all campus buildings, except residence hall rooms, individual study rooms, individual offices, or when eating in dining facilities. Vaccinated students will not have to wear masks except in campus health facilities and on campus transportation."    Operational status of all school districts in SC:   https://archive.vn/r2H0u    SC DHEC webpage on schools and childcare centers: https://web.archive.org/web/20210616205106/https://scdhec.gov/covid19/resources-community-covid-19/schools-childcare-centers-covid-19    SC DHEC school operations guidance document: https://web.archive.org/web/20210523211150/https://scdhec.gov/sites/default/files/media/document/COVID19-School-Operations-Guidance-2021-Final-5.20.21.pdf    University of South Carolina reopening guidelines: https://web.archive.org/web/20210621183339/https://sc.edu/safety/coronavirus/student_family_information/index.php
notes_C2: As of 07 June 2021, Governor McMaster has allowed the State of Emergency (EO No. 2021-25) to expire. EO No. 2021-23 is therefore no longer in effect. There are now no statewide executive orders recommending the use of social distancing or COVID-19 prevention practices. In addition, many businesses are looking to hire new employees.     However, SC DHEC is still encouraging mask-wearing, telework, and disinfection of workplaces (since 12 May 2021). I am keeping the code at 1G to reflect that businesses are open but with significant differences to non-COVID 19 operation (open to revision).    WLTX news article on Governor McMaster ending the SC State of Emergency: https://archive.vn/F9el1  News article on SC job fairs (indicating increased hiring and business reopening): https://archive.vn/AiHGK  SC DHEC businesses and employers webpage: https://web.archive.org/web/20210621152702/https://scdhec.gov/covid19/resources-community-covid-19/businesses-employers-covid-19  SC DHEC workplace reopening guidance: https://web.archive.org/web/20210621152709/https://scdhec.gov/sites/default/files/media/document/COVID19-Reopening-Business-Guidance-05.17.21.pdf
notes_C3: As of 07 June 2021, Governor McMaster has allowed the State of Emergency (EO No. 2021-25) to expire. EO No. 2021-23 is therefore no longer in effect.    No new updates with regard to public events. Although I cannot find evidence to suggest any public event closures on a county or city level, the City of Greenville still suggests following SC guidelines for festivals and special events. This document suggests events follow SC DHEC and CDC recommendations to social distance and control crowds. I am keeping the code at 1T to reflect the COVID-19 related guidelines for public events in the City of Greenville (open to revision).    WLTX news article on Governor McMaster ending the SC State of Emergency: https://archive.vn/F9el1    City of Greenville SC webpage for parades, festivals, parties, and athletic events:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210607192819/https://www.greenvillesc.gov/1346/Event-Permits    SC guidelines for festivals and special events: https://web.archive.org/web/20210327050839/https://accelerate.sc.gov/sites/default/files/Documents/FestivalsandEvents.pdf
notes_C4: As of 07 June 2021, Governor McMaster has allowed the State of Emergency (EO No. 2021-25) to expire. EO No. 2021-23 is therefore no longer in effect. There are no numerical restrictions on gatherings or any general restrictions on private gatherings.     WLTX news article on Governor McMaster ending the SC State of Emergency: https://archive.vn/F9el1
notes_C5: No new updates. Public transportation in the City of Charleston and the City of Greenville do not appear to have any recent COVID-19 related closures or reductions in service.    City of Charleston: https://archive.vn/P1zIA  City of Greenville: https://archive.vn/dzz6y
notes_C6: As of 07 June 2021, Governor McMaster has allowed the State of Emergency (EO No. 2021-25) to expire. EO No. 2021-23 is therefore no longer in effect.    A spot check of the Cities of Charleston, Columbia, and Greenville SC do not appear to have any stay at home orders or curfews in place.    WLTX news article on Governor McMaster ending the SC State of Emergency: https://archive.vn/F9el1
notes_C7: The CDC states: "Delay travel until you are fully vaccinated. If you are not fully vaccinated and must travel, follow CDC’s recommendations for unvaccinated people. . . . You do NOT need to get tested or self-quarantine if you are fully vaccinated or have recovered from COVID-19 in the past 3 months. You should still follow all other travel recommendations."     On 10 June 2021, the CDC updated domestic travel recommendations with the changes in mask guidance for vaccinated vs unvaccinated people:     "Wearing a mask over your nose and mouth is required on planes, buses, trains, and other forms of public transportation traveling into, within, or out of the United States and while indoors at U.S. transportation hubs such as airports and stations. Travelers are not required to wear a mask in outdoor areas of a conveyance (like on a ferry or the top deck of a bus). CDC recommends that travelers who are not fully vaccinated continue to wear a mask and maintain physical distance when traveling."    https://web.archive.org/web/20210618031941/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/travel-during-covid19.html
notes_C8: No new updates. Policy last updated 30 April 2021.    The CDC states:   "With specific exceptions, several Presidential proclamations suspend and limit entry into the United States, as immigrants or nonimmigrants, of noncitizens who were physically present within the following countries during the 14-day period preceding their entry or attempted entry into the United States." This includes fully vaccinated people. See webpage for list of countries.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210618023101/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/from-other-countries.html
notes_E1: The IRS continues to make Economic Impact Payments on a weekly basis to eligible individuals who file a tax return.     As of 09 June 2021:   "Today’s announcement covering the most recent two weeks of the effort brings the total disbursed so far to more than 169 million payments. They represent a total value of approximately $395 billion since these payments began rolling out to Americans in batches on March 12. . . .The last two weeks of payments contain more than 1.2 million direct deposit payments (with a total value over $2.2 billion) with the remainder as paper check payments."    https://web.archive.org/web/20210614181721/https://home.treasury.gov/news/press-releases/jy0219
notes_E2: No new updates. On 21 May 2021, "the U.S. Department of the Treasury announced that it has distributed $6.1 billion through the Emergency Rental Assistance (ERA) program in less than two weeks since $21.6 billion was allocated to the program. A part of the Biden-Harris Administration’s American Rescue Plan, this $21.6 billion ERA program was allocated to prevent evictions and ensure basic housing security for millions of Americans impacted by the affordable housing challenges exacerbated by COVID-19. "    https://web.archive.org/web/20210522172848/https://home.treasury.gov/news/press-releases/jy0193
notes_H1: No new updates. State-wide public information campaigns continue on the South Carolina Department of Health and Environmental Control (SC DHEC) website and twitter page.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210621165826/https://scdhec.gov/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210621165905/https://twitter.com/scdhec
notes_H2: Both symptomatic and asymptomatic people can be tested. The SC DHEC website has more details on who with/without symptoms should be tested (see archived link).     There are many free COVID-19 testing locations around the state. There are three types of COVID tests being offered in SC: PCR, antibody, and rapid antigen (LFT) tests. According to the DHEC webpage, "Those who test positive on a viral test (PCR or antigen) do not need additional testing within the three (3) months following symptom onset or test specimen collection."    SC DHEC does not make a distinction between who can or should receive the PCR vs the rapid antigen test. I am keeping the code as a 3, even though a positive rapid antigen test does not require follow-up with PCR test, because of widespread testing availability.    Who should be tested: https://web.archive.org/web/20210621181201/https://scdhec.gov/covid19/who-should-get-tested-covid-19  Testing sites: https://web.archive.org/web/20210621181156/https://scdhec.gov/covid19/covid-19-testing-locations  COVID testing types:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210621180301/https://scdhec.gov/covid19/covid-19-testing-type-information
notes_H3: No new updates, though I was not able to find any articles or press releases citing the effectiveness of contact tracing in South Carolina since the start of 2021.    The South Carolina DHEC continues to call residents who test positive for COVID-19, as well as to call and inform close contacts of their exposure to COVID-19. Cooperating with the DHEC's contact tracers is "voluntary, confidential and over the phone."    SC DHEC page on contact tracing:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210621182354/https://scdhec.gov/covid19/covid-19-contact-tracing
notes_H6: No new updates. Policy last updated 16 May 2021. "If you are fully vaccinated, you can resume activities that you did prior to the pandemic. Fully vaccinated people can resume activities without wearing a mask or physically distancing, except where required by federal, state, local, tribal, or territorial laws, rules, and regulations, including local business and workplace guidance."    https://web.archive.org/web/20210612011626/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/vaccines/fully-vaccinated.html
notes_H7: No new updates. Since 14 May 2021, everyone 12+ has been eligible for the vaccine. The Pfizer vaccine is approved for those 12 and older. Moderna and Janssen (Johnson & Johnson) vaccines are approved for 18 and up. The vaccine is free, and parental consent is required for those age 12-15.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210621182926/https://scdhec.gov/covid19/covid-19-vaccine

notes_H7: All Tennesseens over 12 years of age are now eligible for vaccination. Pfizer, Moderna and Johnson and Johnson (Janssen) are being used, though only Pfizer is being used on 12-16 year olds.    Vaccine information: https://web.archive.org/web/20210608095336/https://covid19.tn.gov/covid-19-vaccines/ // https://web.archive.org/web/20210608095422/https://covid19.tn.gov/covid-19-vaccines/vaccine-faqs/ // https://web.archive.org/web/20210608095516/https://data.tn.gov/t/Public/views/TennIISCOVID-19VaccineReporting/SUMMARY?%3AshowAppBanner=false&%3Adisplay_count=n&%3AshowVizHome=n&%3Aorigin=viz_share_link&%3Atoolbar=no&%3Aembed=yes // https://web.archive.org/web/20210608095627/https://covid19.tn.gov/

name: Texas
notes_C1: no levels are required to be or are effectively closed in any region of the state.     As of May 10th, essentially all Texas grade schools are offering in-person courses following a statewide mandate. Public schools must offer an in person option in order to "not lose state funding due to declines in enrollment. School districts can require individual students who are falling behind academically to return to in-person classes."    https://web.archive.org/web/20210511015610/https://www.cnn.com/interactive/2020/health/coronavirus-schools-reopening/
notes_C2: Recoded to 1G because no sectors are required to closed, although COVID mitigation policies are still in effect.     As of May 10th, no business sectors are required to close. For the greater state of Texas, Executive Order GA34 is still in effect.  In all counties without high hospitalization, there are no COVID-19 related operation limits for any business or establishments (e.g., gyms, salons, restaurants, public and private schools, childcare services). Businesses can now operate at 100% occupancy, unless county judges use COVID related mitigation strategies-limited to no less than a 50% total occupancy. As of May 10th, no regions are above the threshold for high hospitalization.     The Health Authority Emergency Rules still apply to Austin and Travis counties. These will expire May 18, 2021. Guidelines require  at least 6 feet between groups of 10 or fewer and face coverings in establishments and businesses.       Sources:    https://web.archive.org/web/20210510032836/https://open.texas.gov/uploads/files/organization/opentexas/EO-GA-34-opening-Texas-response-to-COVID-disaster-IMAGE-03-02-2021.pdf    https://web.archive.org/web/20210509001244/https://www.dshs.texas.gov/GA34/    https://web.archive.org/web/20210511020555/https://www.austintexas.gov/department/covid-19-information/orders-rules
notes_C3: Austin-Travis County Interim Health Authority, renewed Health Authority Rules, which expire June 15, 2021. The Emergency Rules govern individuals and sites within the City of Austin and impose requirements to protect public health.     Under the Rules:     Masking remains required in hospitals, health care facilities, long-term care facilities and other congregate settings.    For those who are fully vaccinated, masking remains required unless a business owner allows fully vaccinated individuals to remove their masks indoors with less than 500 people or outdoors with less than 2,500 people.  Outdoor sites with more than 2,500 people may be exempt if the Health Authority approves the site’s COVID-19 precautions.    https://web.archive.org/web/https://www.austintexas.gov/department/covid-19-information/orders-rules
notes_C4: Executive Order GA-32 prohibited outdoor gatherings of more than 10 people unless the event was granted an exemption by the Office of the Mayor. This effectively prohibited outdoor events in Austin.    Executive Order GA-34 went into effect on March 10?by Austin-Travis County Interim Health Authority and?allows?all businesses to operate at 100%?capacity?including?wedding venues, sports and entertainment venues, performance halls,?bars and music venues.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210520152137/https://austintexas.gov/page/special-events-updates-covid-19
notes_C5: As of May 11th, there are still no major public transit closures statewide.
notes_C6: As of May 11th, 2021, Travis County, which includes Austin, remains in stage three, where guidelines state that unvaccinated or partially vaccinated people at high risk (e.g., 65+, high blood pressure, diabetes) are encouraged to avoid non-essential dining and shopping but there is no requirement. There are no statewide recommendations or requirements to stay home.     Sources: https://web.archive.org/web/20210512040934/https://www.austintexas.gov/page/covid-19-risk-based-guidelines
notes_C7: As of May 4th, 2021 Austin and Travis county remain in stage 3. Guidelines now only advise unvaccinated or partially vaccinated people at high risk (e.g., 65+, high blood pressure, diabetes) to avoid non essential travel, but this is not a legal requirement. There are no further recommendations or restrictions statewide. As a result, coding changed to a 1T.     Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210512040934/https://www.austintexas.gov/page/covid-19-risk-based-guidelines
notes_C8: No new updates. Policy last updated 30 April 2021.    The CDC states:   "With specific exceptions, several Presidential proclamations suspend and limit entry into the United States, as immigrants or nonimmigrants, of noncitizens who were physically present within the following countries during the 14-day period preceding their entry or attempted entry into the United States." This includes fully vaccinated people. See webpage for list of countries.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210614181209/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/from-other-countries.html
notes_E1: As of May 3, 2021, the Texas Rent Relief Program continues (Launched Feb.15, 2021). The program provides monetary assistance to households in paying rent or utilities, Qualifying households can make no more than 80% of an area’s median income. Priority will be given to households making less than 50% of an areas median income or household members unemployed for at least 90 days.  Links:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210503222919/https://texasrentrelief.com/     https://web.archive.org/web/20210209191920/https://www.statesman.com/story/news/politics/state/2021/02/09/texas-gov-greg-abbott-rent-relief-program-launches-covid-pandemic/4449250001/
notes_E2: As of May 3, 2021 the Texas Eviction Diversion Program remains in effect.       Link to the TEDP:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210426163402/https://www.tdhca.state.tx.us/TEDP.htm     https://web.archive.org/web/20210217203258/https://www.txcourts.gov/media/1451765/219015.pdf
notes_H1: As of May 3, 2021, up to date information on covid is still provided through social media (e.g., twitter) and the Texas government website.    Links:    https://web.archive.org/web/20210503223102/https://www.texas.gov/covid19/     https://archive.vn/cYfUc
notes_H2: PCR Testing is available to the population , but no details specific to LTF   http://webarchive/web/20210614171907/https://www.urgentcaretexas.com/departments/covid-19-testing/
notes_H3: As of May 3, 2021 contact tracing efforts continue in Texas but participation in efforts is voluntary. Texas currently has 3192 tracers.    Links:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210503223949/https://www.dshs.state.tx.us/coronavirus/tracing.aspx     https://web.archive.org/web/20210503212531/https://testandtrace.com/state-data/
notes_H6: Austin-Travis County Interim Health Authority, renewed Health Authority Rules, which expire June 15, 2021. The Emergency Rules govern individuals and sites within the City of Austin and impose requirements to protect public health.     Under the Rules:     Masking remains required in hospitals, health care facilities, long-term care facilities and other congregate settings.    For those who are fully vaccinated, masking remains required unless a business owner allows fully vaccinated individuals to remove their masks indoors with less than 500 people or outdoors with less than 2,500 people.  Outdoor sites with more than 2,500 people may be exempt if the Health Authority approves the site’s COVID-19 precautions.    https://web.archive.org/web/https://www.austintexas.gov/department/covid-19-information/orders-rules
notes_H7: As of May 3, 2021 Texas eligibility for COVID-19 vaccination remains open to individuals aged 16+.     Moderna vaccine is being used for individuals 18 and older, while the Pfizer vaccine is authorized for people 16 and older. The Texas Health commissioner is now asking that sites now resume use of the  Johnson & Johnson/Janssen COVID-19 vaccine, after US health officials ended their vaccine halt (Friday April 23, 2021).    Texas State Vaccination Requirement Link:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210503223729/https://dshs.texas.gov/coronavirus/immunize/vaccine.aspx     Texas DSHS/ News Vaccine Update:  https://archive.vn/cYfUc        Continuation of  J&J Vaccine:    https://web.archive.org/web/20210426164412/https://www.usnews.com/news/best-states/texas/articles/2021-04-24/texas-health-commissioner-says-j-j-vaccines-should-resume

name: Utah
notes_C1: The previous note is still valid : "While the state-wide mask mandate for K-12 schools was revoked on May 15th 2021, Davis School District will continue to follow other safety guidelines, including social distancing (when possible), and periodic testing of unvaccinated students, until the beginning of the Fall semester on August 23rd when all restrictions and guidelines will be removed."    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210621145629/https://www.davis.k12.ut.us/departments/risk-management/covid19
notes_C2: As of June 21st, Uintah County remains the only county at the high transmission tier. No closings are required, but distancing measures are in effect.    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210621150147/https://coronavirus.utah.gov/utah-health-guidance-levels/
notes_C3: As of June 21st, there are no changes in this indicator. The previous note is still valid: "On May 4th, Utah lifted restrictions on gatherings and distancing. Masks are no longer required regardless of county spread levels. Mitigation measures are still recommended at gatherings statewide.”  Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210518040319/https://www.abc4.com/coronavirus/utah-reaches-criteria-to-lift-covid-19-public-health-orders/   Source:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210621150147/https://coronavirus.utah.gov/utah-health-guidance-levels/
notes_C4: The previous note is still valid: "On May 4th, Utah lifted all restrictions on gatherings and distancing. Masks are no longer required regardless of county spread levels. Mitigation measures are still recommended at gatherings statewide.   Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210518040319/https://www.abc4.com/coronavirus/utah-reaches-criteria-to-lift-covid-19-public-health-orders/   Source:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210621150147/https://coronavirus.utah.gov/utah-health-guidance-levels/
notes_C5: There are no restrictions in place for this indicator.
notes_C6: There are no restrictions in place for this indicator.
notes_C7: The CDC states: "Delay travel until you are fully vaccinated. If you are not fully vaccinated and must travel, follow CDC’s recommendations for unvaccinated people. . . . You do NOT need to get tested or self-quarantine if you are fully vaccinated or have recovered from COVID-19 in the past 3 months. You should still follow all other travel recommendations."     On 10 June 2021, the CDC updated domestic travel recommendations with the changes in mask guidance for vaccinated vs unvaccinated people:     "Wearing a mask over your nose and mouth is required on planes, buses, trains, and other forms of public transportation traveling into, within, or out of the United States and while indoors at U.S. transportation hubs such as airports and stations. Travelers are not required to wear a mask in outdoor areas of a conveyance (like on a ferry or the top deck of a bus). CDC recommends that travelers who are not fully vaccinated continue to wear a mask and maintain physical distance when traveling."    https://web.archive.org/web/20210618031941/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/travel-during-covid19.html
notes_C8: No new updates. Policy last updated 30 April 2021.    The CDC states:   "With specific exceptions, several Presidential proclamations suspend and limit entry into the United States, as immigrants or nonimmigrants, of noncitizens who were physically present within the following countries during the 14-day period preceding their entry or attempted entry into the United States." This includes fully vaccinated people. See webpage for list of countries.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210618023101/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/from-other-countries.html
notes_E1: The IRS continues to make Economic Impact Payments on a weekly basis to eligible individuals who file a tax return.     As of 09 June 2021:   "Today’s announcement covering the most recent two weeks of the effort brings the total disbursed so far to more than 169 million payments. They represent a total value of approximately $395 billion since these payments began rolling out to Americans in batches on March 12. . . .The last two weeks of payments contain more than 1.2 million direct deposit payments (with a total value over $2.2 billion) with the remainder as paper check payments."    https://web.archive.org/web/20210614181721/https://home.treasury.gov/news/press-releases/jy0219
notes_E2: No new updates. On 21 May 2021, "the U.S. Department of the Treasury announced that it has distributed $6.1 billion through the Emergency Rental Assistance (ERA) program in less than two weeks since $21.6 billion was allocated to the program. A part of the Biden-Harris Administration’s American Rescue Plan, this $21.6 billion ERA program was allocated to prevent evictions and ensure basic housing security for millions of Americans impacted by the affordable housing challenges exacerbated by COVID-19. "    https://web.archive.org/web/20210522172848/https://home.treasury.gov/news/press-releases/jy0193
notes_H1: The state government continues to maintain a coordinated public information campaign online.   Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210616141151/https://coronavirus.utah.gov/utah-health-guidance-levels/
notes_H2: The previous note is still valid: "Testing available to those who are symptomatic and/or who made effective contact with someone who has COVID-19."    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210616143035/https://coronavirus.utah.gov/testing-locations/
notes_H3: As of June 16, contact tracing continues. However, the state contact tracing website states that "Some health departments are not able to do contact tracing right now and are focusing their limited and strained resources on case investigations. If you were exposed to someone who has COVID-19 you should quarantine for 14 days, even if the health department doesn’t contact you."    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210616143035/https://coronavirus.utah.gov/testing-locations/
notes_H6: The previous note is still valid: "Following multiple local school districts' movements to cancel in-school mask mandates, Governor Cox lifted the statewide K-12 masking requirement for the last week of school. The K-12 masking mandate [was terminated] on May 15th.   Masks are still required in certain public spaces by local mandate, and may be required by businesses. For instance, by mayoral order, masks are required in all municipal buildings in Salt Lake City."    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210518033234/https://www.sltrib.com/news/2021/05/13/watch-live-gov-spencer/  Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210616143658/https://www.slc.gov/blog/2021/05/11/salt-lake-city-mayor-erin-mendenhall-signs-executive-order-requiring-masks-in-city-facilities/
notes_H7: The previous note is still valid: "On May 13th, Utah began vaccinating minors aged 12-15. Children in this age group are only eligible to receive Pfizer vaccine. Moderna and J&J vaccines are being administered for those 18+."  Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210616144114/https://coronavirus.utah.gov/vaccine-distribution/

notes_H7: As of 14 June 2021, all individuals aged 12 and above are eligible for vaccination.   Those aged 12-15 are eligible for the Pfizer vaccination.  Individuals aged 16 and above are eligible for the Pfizer, Moderna and J&J vaccines.  http://web.archive.org/web/20210614224655/https://www.healthvermont.gov/covid-19
