name: Wisconsin
notes_C1: All restrictions in Dane County and Milwaukee have recently been lifted, there is a lack of documentation of restrictions in other areas of the state (i.e. many sources are now calling the state "fully reopened").    https://web.archive.org/web/20210622102201/https://pbswisconsin.org/news-item/wisconsins-covid-condition-pandemic-metrics-plunge-the-last-local-rules-expire/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210622102248/https://www.aarp.org/politics-society/government-elections/info-2020/coronavirus-state-restrictions.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210622102501/https://www.usatoday.com/storytelling/coronavirus-reopening-america-map/
notes_C2: Policy last updated June 14, 2021 to include information on fully vaccinated people, which resulted in NO change to the policy.    The CDC recommendations include risk mitigation but does not recommend closures. The "Guidance for Businesses and Employers Responding to Coronavirus Disease 2019 (COVID-19)" was last updated on 31 December 2020 and also doesn't recommend closures.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210615113611/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/community/organizations/business-employers/bars-restaurants.html    https://web.archive.org/web/20210621171029/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/community/guidance-business-response.html
notes_C3: No new updates. Policy last updated 20 May 2021: "Updated cleaning and disinfection information"    The CDC "continues to recommend avoiding large events and gatherings. Currently, CDC does not provide numbers to define small and large events."    https://web.archive.org/web/20210620185116/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/community/large-events/considerations-for-events-gatherings.html
notes_C4: All restrictions in Dane County and Milwaukee have recently been lifted, there is a lack of documentation of restrictions in other areas of the state (i.e. many sources are now calling the state "fully reopened"). Gatherings are recommended to be outside, in well-ventilated areas, but there are no specific size limitations.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210622103925/https://www.jsonline.com/story/news/local/milwaukee/2021/05/13/city-milwaukee-ending-some-covid-19-restrictions-june-15/5071027001/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210622103713/https://www.dhs.wisconsin.gov/covid-19/community.htm  https://web.archive.org/web/20210622102201/https://pbswisconsin.org/news-item/wisconsins-covid-condition-pandemic-metrics-plunge-the-last-local-rules-expire/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210622102248/https://www.aarp.org/politics-society/government-elections/info-2020/coronavirus-state-restrictions.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210622102501/https://www.usatoday.com/storytelling/coronavirus-reopening-america-map/
notes_C5: All restrictions in Dane County and Milwaukee have recently been lifted, there is a lack of documentation of restrictions in other areas of the state (i.e. many sources are now calling the state "fully reopened").    https://web.archive.org/web/20210622102201/https://pbswisconsin.org/news-item/wisconsins-covid-condition-pandemic-metrics-plunge-the-last-local-rules-expire/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210622102248/https://www.aarp.org/politics-society/government-elections/info-2020/coronavirus-state-restrictions.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210622102501/https://www.usatoday.com/storytelling/coronavirus-reopening-america-map/
notes_C6: All restrictions in Dane County and Milwaukee have recently been lifted, there is a lack of documentation of restrictions in other areas of the state (i.e. many sources are now calling the state "fully reopened").    https://web.archive.org/web/20210622102201/https://pbswisconsin.org/news-item/wisconsins-covid-condition-pandemic-metrics-plunge-the-last-local-rules-expire/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210622102248/https://www.aarp.org/politics-society/government-elections/info-2020/coronavirus-state-restrictions.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210622102501/https://www.usatoday.com/storytelling/coronavirus-reopening-america-map/
notes_C7: The CDC states: "Delay travel until you are fully vaccinated. If you are not fully vaccinated and must travel, follow CDC’s recommendations for unvaccinated people. . . . You do NOT need to get tested or self-quarantine if you are fully vaccinated or have recovered from COVID-19 in the past 3 months. You should still follow all other travel recommendations."     On 10 June 2021, the CDC updated domestic travel recommendations with the changes in mask guidance for vaccinated vs unvaccinated people:     "Wearing a mask over your nose and mouth is required on planes, buses, trains, and other forms of public transportation traveling into, within, or out of the United States and while indoors at U.S. transportation hubs such as airports and stations. Travelers are not required to wear a mask in outdoor areas of a conveyance (like on a ferry or the top deck of a bus). CDC recommends that travelers who are not fully vaccinated continue to wear a mask and maintain physical distance when traveling."    https://web.archive.org/web/20210618031941/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/travel-during-covid19.html
notes_C8: No new updates. Policy last updated 30 April 2021.    The CDC states:   "With specific exceptions, several Presidential proclamations suspend and limit entry into the United States, as immigrants or nonimmigrants, of noncitizens who were physically present within the following countries during the 14-day period preceding their entry or attempted entry into the United States." This includes fully vaccinated people. See webpage for list of countries.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210618023101/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/from-other-countries.html
notes_E1: As of December 1st, the Department of Workforce Development still detailed unemployment benefits, as well as several extensions to benefits due to the pandemic.     See archive:   http://web.archive.org/web/20201201011650/https://dwd.wisconsin.gov/covid19/public/ui.htm#collapse1-23
notes_E2: As of February 1, 2021, the annual winter moratorium on utilities, which lasts until April 15, 2021, is still in effect. Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20201029025941/https://apps.psc.wi.gov/APPS/NewsReleases/content/PDF_download.aspx?id=663
notes_H1: As of 8 March, the Wisconsin Department of Health Services is still operating a coordinated public health information campaign.    Source:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210304145019/https://www.dhs.wisconsin.gov/covid-19/index.htm
notes_H2: As of 8 March, testing is still generally available through primary care providers, community testing sites and at home specimen kits (at no cost to Wisconsinites).    Source:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210220021543/https://www.dhs.wisconsin.gov/covid-19/testing.htm
notes_H3: As of 8 March, a comprehensive contact tracing system remains in place.     Source:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210301144135/https://www.dhs.wisconsin.gov/covid-19/contact-tracing.htm
notes_H6: Masks are required for those who are unvaccinated in indoor spaces. Masks are not required for vaccinated individuals except in certain circumstances, including public transportation and correctional facilities.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210622103228/https://www.dhs.wisconsin.gov/covid-19/mask.htm
notes_H7: Pfizer, Moderna, and Johnson & Johnson vaccines are available in Wisconsin. Roughly 46% of people 12 and up are fully vaccinated as of June 21.    Sources:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210515235126/https://covidactnow.org/us/wisconsin-wi/?s=1837755  https://web.archive.org/web/20210515235414/https://www.dhs.wisconsin.gov/covid-19/vaccine-get.htm  https://web.archive.org/web/20210516162604/https://www.wbay.com/2021/05/15/state-sees-jump-in-number-of-kids-age-12-15-receiving-first-covid-19-shot/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210524185215/https://wkow.com/2021/05/21/8-new-covid-19-deaths-in-wisconsin-40-5-fully-vaccinated/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210531194706/https://www.dhs.wisconsin.gov/covid-19/vaccine-data.htm

name: West Virginia
notes_C1: No change in policy as of 6 June 2021.    “All students will attend in-person instruction five, full days per week effective March 24, 2021.    A local county board of education retains the authority to work with local health officials and to close individual classrooms or schools when a specific health need related to that classroom or school is identified. Such closures shall be of limited duration and related to the specific health need of the school or classroom. Teachers and staff will continue to provide essential student support services including meals, student engagement, all special education services and support to at-risk students.    Counties that are utilizing classroom teachers to teach both in-person students and full-time students participating in locally designed virtual programs may submit a waiver request to the State Superintendent to request the ability to conduct in-person instruction four days per week to allow sufficient time to support full-time virtual students.    Parents will continue to have the ability to choose a virtual learning option for their children.”    The West Virginia department of education also outlines key mitigation strategies, including “social distancing to the largest extent.”    https://web.archive.org/web/20210606042537/https://wvde.us/school-recovery-protocols/
notes_C2: Most recent update March 8th.     Policy unchanged.      The CDC recommendations include risk mitigation but does not recommend closures. The "Guidance for Businesses and Employers Responding to Coronavirus Disease 2019 (COVID-19)" was last updated on December 31st, 2020 and also doesn't recommend closures.     See archive:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210517035029/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/community/guidance-business-response.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210520164202/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/community/organizations/business-employers/bars-restaurants.html
notes_C3: Given that there was no announced policy change on public events before 1st May 2021, we can assume that the resumption of "all fairs, festivals, and summer camps" has taken place. This is allowed "provided that all such events follow all applicable safety guidelines", which is reflected in the ongoing 1G rating of this indicator.     Source:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210427205619/https://governor.wv.gov/The-Comeback/Pages/default.aspx
notes_C4: no measures found as of 6 June 2021.    https://archive.fo/606o2
notes_C5: no measures regarding transportation found as of 6 June 2021.    https://archive.vn/cmTf8
notes_C6: no measures regarding a stay at home order found as of 6 June 2021.    https://archive.fo/dkSj2
notes_C7: code as 0 since there are no additional international travel restrictions beyond those of the federal government as of 6 June 2021.    https://archive.fo/dkSj2
notes_C8: Last updated Apr 30th, 2021. The previous policy coding remains unchanged.     The CDC states:   "With specific exceptions, several Presidential proclamations suspend and limit entry into the United States, as immigrants or nonimmigrants, of noncitizens who were physically present within the following countries during the 14-day period preceding their entry or attempted entry into the United States." This includes fully vaccinated people.     See archive:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210523000705/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/from-other-countries.html
notes_E1: no change in policy found as of 6 June 2021 so continue to code as 1F. However, “Justice said Friday, and reiterated Monday, that he is ordering the $300 payments cut off from West Virginians effective June 19.”    https://archive.fo/gKXXY  https://archive.fo/nMDrz
notes_E2: On May 21st,   "the U.S. Department of the Treasury announced that it has distributed $6.1 billion through the Emergency Rental Assistance (ERA) program in less than two weeks since $21.6 billion was allocated to the program. A part of the Biden-Harris Administration’s American Rescue Plan, this $21.6 billion ERA program was allocated to prevent evictions and ensure basic housing security for millions of Americans impacted by the affordable housing challenges exacerbated by COVID-19. "    See archive:     https://web.archive.org/web/20210522172848/https://home.treasury.gov/news/press-releases/jy0193
notes_H1: Code as 2G as of 6 June 2021. West Virginia continues to offer vaccination incentives as well as keep the public updated on important COVID-related information.    Effective 4 June 2021, “The giveaway will include a $1.588 million grand prize, a $588,000 second prize, full scholarships to any higher education institution in West Virginia, custom-outfitted trucks, weekend vacations at state parks, lifetime hunting and fishing licenses, custom hunting rifles and custom hunting shotguns.”    https://archive.fo/oNwZa
notes_H2: no change in policy found as of 6 June 2021. Continue to code as 3 since testing is free and available to all residents, including those without symptoms.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210606174456/https://dhhr.wv.gov/COVID-19/Pages/testing.aspx
notes_H3: no change in policy found as of 6 June 2021 so continue to code as 1. However, as mentioned in an earlier note, it is difficult to find information about contact tracing, especially at the state level. Given the quote below from the West Virginia Department of Health and Human Services’ Guidelines for Outbreaks in Schools, contact tracing seems to be the responsibility of local health departments.    “The local health department should work with the school to establish list of close contacts (a tool for contact tracing can be found at the end of this document). In working with the local health department, the school or local health department will notify close contacts that they have been exposed and provide recommendations for quarantine.”    https://archive.fo/47rzC
notes_H6: no change in policy found as of 6 June 2021 so continue to code as 2G. “Statewide Indoor Face Covering Requirement is still in effect for all West Virginians who are not yet fully vaccinated, and will remain in effect for these individuals until June 20, 2021.” The face covering requirement does not apply to fully vaccinated individuals.    https://archive.fo/HkW1A
notes_H7: no change in policy found as of 6 June 2021. All individuals ages 12 and older continue to be eligible for the vaccine.    https://archive.fo/RuiSN

name: Wyoming
notes_C1: "Beginning June 1, 2021, statewide public health orders will no longer be in effect. Moving forward, unless circumstances warrant additional statewide or local orders, specific protocols for the safe operation of K-12 schools during the pandemic will be determined at the school district level." Mask requirements are dropped but are still recommended and deferred to district level guidelines.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210607220427/https://health.wyo.gov/wp-content/uploads/2021/05/WDH-COVID-19-Guidance-for-K-12-Schools-.pdf  https://web.archive.org/web/20210607220021if_/https://www.tcsd.org/6/News/193#sthash.vOBNTHQc.dpbs
notes_C2: As of June 7, 2021, there are no statewide orders recommending closure of restaurants, bars, etc. However,  statewide public health orders still encourage social distancing and other COVID-19 prevention measures. For this reason the code is 1G.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210607221150/https://health.wyo.gov/news/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210607221402/https://covid19.wyo.gov/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210607221620/https://covid19.wyo.gov/governors-orders  https://web.archive.org/web/20210607221629/https://governor.wyo.gov/
notes_C3: The policy was updated on May 20th: "Updated cleaning and disinfection information"    The policy coding remains unchanged.     The CDC "continues to recommend avoiding large events and gatherings. Currently, CDC does not provide numbers to define small and large events."    See archive:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210607003740/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/community/large-events/considerations-for-events-gatherings.html
notes_C4: As of June 7, 2021, no changes to end of restrictions on gatherings from Public Health Order #2 on May 21, 2021.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210607221150/https://health.wyo.gov/news/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210607221402/https://covid19.wyo.gov/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210607221620/https://covid19.wyo.gov/governors-orders  https://web.archive.org/web/20210607221629/https://governor.wyo.gov/
notes_C5: As of June 7, 2021 there are no new updates. Bus service remains suspended in Cheyenne.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210607222148/https://www.cheyennecity.org/Your-Government/Departments/Public-Works/Transit
notes_C6: As of June 7, 2021, there are no executive or public health orders to shelter-in-place.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210607221150/https://health.wyo.gov/news/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210607221402/https://covid19.wyo.gov/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210607221620/https://covid19.wyo.gov/governors-orders  https://web.archive.org/web/20210607221629/https://governor.wyo.gov/
notes_C7: The CDC states:   If vaccinated "You do NOT need to get tested or self-quarantine if you are fully vaccinated or have recovered from COVID-19 in the past 3 months. You should still follow all other travel recommendations." and recommends wearing masks/social distancing while traveling.     If unvaccinated to be tested prior, adhere to social distancing/mask-wearing, and self-quarantining/testing following travel.     See archive:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210607003622/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/travel-during-covid19.html
notes_C8: Last updated Apr 30th, 2021. The previous policy coding remains unchanged.     The CDC states:   "With specific exceptions, several Presidential proclamations suspend and limit entry into the United States, as immigrants or nonimmigrants, of noncitizens who were physically present within the following countries during the 14-day period preceding their entry or attempted entry into the United States." This includes fully vaccinated people.     See archive:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210606105605/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/from-other-countries.html
notes_E1: On May 5th, the treasury stated that they sent out an additional 1.1 million payments to individuals that were missed in the earlier dispersal of one-time payments.     This coding remains at 1F as these payments were residual payments from the earlier, one-time payments.     Currently, there is still financial support in the form of unemployment that is dispersed to states.     See archive: https://web.archive.org/web/20210506003943/https://home.treasury.gov/news/press-releases/jy0161
notes_E2: On May 21st,   "the U.S. Department of the Treasury announced that it has distributed $6.1 billion through the Emergency Rental Assistance (ERA) program in less than two weeks since $21.6 billion was allocated to the program. A part of the Biden-Harris Administration’s American Rescue Plan, this $21.6 billion ERA program was allocated to prevent evictions and ensure basic housing security for millions of Americans impacted by the affordable housing challenges exacerbated by COVID-19. "    See archive:     https://web.archive.org/web/20210522172848/https://home.treasury.gov/news/press-releases/jy0193
notes_H1: As of June 7, 2021, the Wyoming Department of Health (WDH) continues to have a COVID-19 website, which is highly informative and is updated on a regular basis. For this reason code remains 2G.    Other social media sources such as the WDH or Governor Mark Gordon’s twitter pages are very outdated or are not being used for any COVID communications.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210607224631/https://health.wyo.gov/publichealth/infectious-disease-epidemiology-unit/disease/novel-coronavirus/covid-19-orders-and-guidance/    https://web.archive.org/web/20210607230103/https://twitter.com/health_wyoming  https://web.archive.org/web/20210607230253/https://twitter.com/mark_gordon_wy
notes_H2: As of June 7, 2021, Wyoming continues to offer free at-home testing for anyone who wants to be tested for COVID-19 through a company called Vault Health. Vault Health also provides workplace testing.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210605205249/https://health.wyo.gov/publichealth/infectious-disease-epidemiology-unit/disease/novel-coronavirus/covid-19-at-home-testing/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210607230337/https://health.wyo.gov/publichealth/infectious-disease-epidemiology-unit/disease/novel-coronavirus/covid-19-workplace-testing/
notes_H3: Since January 2021, limited contact tracing is being done on a regional level. Teton County continues to call people who test positive for COVID-19.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210607230732/https://www.hcn.org/articles/north-covid19-wyomings-last-contact-tracers  https://web.archive.org/web/20210301134936/https://undark.org/2021/01/05/wyoming-state-stops-contact-tracing/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210607230847/https://www.tetoncountywy.gov/2158/Isolation-Quarantine-and-Contact-Tracing
notes_H6: The Teton County Public Health Order First Continuation #21-3 order (effective May 7, 2021), rescinded the mask requirement for Teton county. So, as of May 23 2021, there is now currently no mask mandate across Wyoming as a whole.    Nevertheless, according to the Public Health Order #21-4 effective June 1 - June 11, 2021, k-12 schools are still required to wear masks inside buildings. Because this specification is not based on location but is a restriction on people, code is 2G.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210607231324/http://www.tetoncountywy.gov/DocumentCenter/View/18564/TetonCountyOrder21-4Signed210524-2  https://web.archive.org/web/20210607220427/https://health.wyo.gov/wp-content/uploads/2021/05/WDH-COVID-19-Guidance-for-K-12-Schools-.pdf
notes_H7: As of June 7, 2021, the general public can get vaccinated in Wyoming (16+ for Pfizer, 18+ for Moderna and J&J). For this reason, universal vaccination is available so code is 5G.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210607231656/https://health.wyo.gov/publichealth/immunization/wyoming-covid-19-vaccine-information/
